guides.title: How to Make a Repair Guide
guides.raw_content:
# How to Make a Repair Guide

Learn two skills at once—restring a guitar and take great photographs for guides.

## 1. Step 1
- This guide shows you how to replace your guitar strings and improve your photography skills!
- The photography setup doesn't have to be fancy. All you need is a camera, tripod, and some carefully-placed lights.
- Before you start taking your real shots, take some sample pictures to test your lighting.
![Step 1 Image 6990](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/xmFJGebKxDkCSTLL.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/xmFJGebKxDkCSTLL.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/xmFJGebKxDkCSTLL.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/xmFJGebKxDkCSTLL.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/xmFJGebKxDkCSTLL.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Before you start taking your real shots, take some sample pictures to test your lighting.
> **Note:** Pay attention to:
  - How "white" your whites are
  - Shadows and reflections
  - Under- and overexposure
- Auto-white-balance sometimes doesn't function properly. If you're indoors, use the tungsten or incandescent (3000K range) setting. If you're outdoors, select daylight (5600K). On some cameras you can also automatically set white balance by taking a picture of a sheet of paper.
- When you take pictures on a light background, the picture will sometimes appear too dark. To compensate for this, increase the exposure.
> **Note:** Once you have a lighting setup that you're happy with, leave it the same for the entire shoot.
![Step 2 Image 6908](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AxgSVavoLkX56iQ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AxgSVavoLkX56iQ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AxgSVavoLkX56iQ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AxgSVavoLkX56iQ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AxgSVavoLkX56iQ.full -->
![Step 2 Image 6909](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MnplsjmcVQOYrLc5.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MnplsjmcVQOYrLc5.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MnplsjmcVQOYrLc5.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MnplsjmcVQOYrLc5.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MnplsjmcVQOYrLc5.full -->
![Step 2 Image 6910](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OlMs6BkOlblQHgNj.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OlMs6BkOlblQHgNj.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OlMs6BkOlblQHgNj.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OlMs6BkOlblQHgNj.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OlMs6BkOlblQHgNj.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- Find a location that has plenty of light. Don't use a background that's too visually complex.
- Use two lamps on the object, one on each side.
- It may be tempting, but don't rotate the camera to take portrait shots. For layout consistency, we require all photos have a landscape 4:3 aspect ratio.
- Mount the camera to a tripod if you can. Most of today's cameras work great for taking guide pictures. All of the guitar pictures were taken using a [link|http://www.amazon.com/Canon-PowerShot-S410-Digital-Optical/dp/B0001G6U5M|Canon PowerShot S410].
- It certainly helps to hook the camera up to your computer after your few initial shots to see how they look on a bigger screen.
![Step 3 Image 6912](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oqENf6clhPRbODw2.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oqENf6clhPRbODw2.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oqENf6clhPRbODw2.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oqENf6clhPRbODw2.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oqENf6clhPRbODw2.full -->
![Step 3 Image 7077](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/y1DXWuW5QmcZ14Bu.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/y1DXWuW5QmcZ14Bu.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/y1DXWuW5QmcZ14Bu.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/y1DXWuW5QmcZ14Bu.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/y1DXWuW5QmcZ14Bu.full -->
![Step 3 Image 7125](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6ltGSQRcuEZG3sM2.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6ltGSQRcuEZG3sM2.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6ltGSQRcuEZG3sM2.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6ltGSQRcuEZG3sM2.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6ltGSQRcuEZG3sM2.full -->

## 4. Step 4
> **Note:** Allowing the camera to auto-focus should be fine most of the time. However, in rare circumstances the camera focuses on the background instead of the object you're trying to capture. You can zoom in on the object or move the object away from the background.
- Many cameras have a close-up or macro mode (often termed the 'flower' setting). Use this mode if your subject is less than 2 feet from the camera.
- Shoot at the highest resolution possible so you have more flexibility when cropping the shot. We require you upload an image that is at least 800 x 600 pixels.
- Set your ISO to the lowest possible number (ideally 50-200 ISO). The ISO setting adjusts the camera's sensitivity to light. The higher this setting, the grainier the photo will be.
![Step 4 Image 7078](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/LxKJIMOMAB21M1GN.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/LxKJIMOMAB21M1GN.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/LxKJIMOMAB21M1GN.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/LxKJIMOMAB21M1GN.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/LxKJIMOMAB21M1GN.full -->
![Step 4 Image 7079](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Ujw5gCasCEkYaWOj.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Ujw5gCasCEkYaWOj.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Ujw5gCasCEkYaWOj.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Ujw5gCasCEkYaWOj.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Ujw5gCasCEkYaWOj.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- Finally, on to the guitar string instructions: Unwind the guitar key.
- It's important to have your hand in the shot in order to convey the action being performed.
- This can be difficult. It's easy to get your arm in the shot, or have your hand obstruct what you're trying to show.
- Fill the frame with the part of the subject pertinent to the step you're describing. When in doubt, go closer - but don't use digital zoom.
- A lone person can often take all the pictures with a fair amount of dexterity and the help of a tripod. Of course, practice makes perfect!
- Most cameras have a short (2-10 second) timer option that can free your hands for a shot. This will also eliminate camera shake from pressing the shutter button.
![Step 5 Image 7080](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2isJTPwgBtOZbj61.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2isJTPwgBtOZbj61.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2isJTPwgBtOZbj61.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2isJTPwgBtOZbj61.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2isJTPwgBtOZbj61.full -->
![Step 5 Image 7081](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dYRCAnwkylTa1RMV.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dYRCAnwkylTa1RMV.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dYRCAnwkylTa1RMV.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dYRCAnwkylTa1RMV.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dYRCAnwkylTa1RMV.full -->
![Step 5 Image 7083](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QxZdnGpJHAcWIlJW.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QxZdnGpJHAcWIlJW.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QxZdnGpJHAcWIlJW.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QxZdnGpJHAcWIlJW.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QxZdnGpJHAcWIlJW.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- Remove the bridge pin to free the other side of the string.
- Sometimes, you need to take the picture slightly differently than you would actually perform the task. Some things are impossible to show the actual action.
- Removing a bridge pin takes some force wiggling back and forth, which you can't show in a picture. In this case, we removed the pin ahead of time, then put it back for the picture.
- It's more important to show the 'goal' of the shot than the actual action. In this case, pulling the pin partially out shows the viewer what the complete pin looks like, even though the task is essentially complete by the time the photo is taken.
- Make sure that your hand (or any other object) does not interfere with the action being performed.
![Step 6 Image 7093](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NxxdYvoyBV3nbj6I.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NxxdYvoyBV3nbj6I.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NxxdYvoyBV3nbj6I.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NxxdYvoyBV3nbj6I.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NxxdYvoyBV3nbj6I.full -->
![Step 6 Image 7094](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VE4XqnXlFgD1UfV6.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VE4XqnXlFgD1UfV6.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VE4XqnXlFgD1UfV6.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VE4XqnXlFgD1UfV6.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VE4XqnXlFgD1UfV6.full -->
![Step 6 Image 7096](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hwVAp3Hlc6UXTkpH.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hwVAp3Hlc6UXTkpH.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hwVAp3Hlc6UXTkpH.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hwVAp3Hlc6UXTkpH.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hwVAp3Hlc6UXTkpH.full -->

## 7. Step 7
- Thread the new guitar string through the bridge pin, and position it along the appropriate string guide.
- Insert the pin fully into its hole.
> **Note:** The only time two people are really necessary is when both hands are needed in the shot.
- You can often get a better angle on the shot if you prop up the object.
![Step 7 Image 7097](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MctqoToAILktpQuH.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MctqoToAILktpQuH.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MctqoToAILktpQuH.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MctqoToAILktpQuH.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MctqoToAILktpQuH.full -->
![Step 7 Image 7100](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BHPVnSc63ZTMbf2p.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BHPVnSc63ZTMbf2p.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BHPVnSc63ZTMbf2p.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BHPVnSc63ZTMbf2p.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BHPVnSc63ZTMbf2p.full -->

## 8. Step 8
- Insert the other side of the guitar string through the keyhole of the guitar peg.
- For fine tasks like this, zoom way in the action.
- Adjust the tripod legs so two legs are much shorter than the third. This allows you to cantilever the camera over the shot to get a more vertical angle.
- If it's hard to show an action from just one angle, take two or three pictures for the same step.
![Step 8 Image 7098](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tsGS4VPVIUt2PTEM.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tsGS4VPVIUt2PTEM.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tsGS4VPVIUt2PTEM.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tsGS4VPVIUt2PTEM.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tsGS4VPVIUt2PTEM.full -->

## 9. Step 9
- Wind the string until it is somewhat tight, and then press it into the fretboard channel.
- Continue winding until it is close to being tuned.
![Step 9 Image 7101](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J5XDWcYBahc2FvAd.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J5XDWcYBahc2FvAd.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J5XDWcYBahc2FvAd.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J5XDWcYBahc2FvAd.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J5XDWcYBahc2FvAd.full -->

## 10. Step 10
- Use a guitar tuner to check the tune of the string. Adjust accordingly until the string is properly tuned.
- This picture managed to capture:
  - A clear representation of the performed action (both person and object)
  - The end result that's being achieved
> **Note:** For every picture you take, you have to ask yourself: "What am I trying to convey with this picture?"
![Step 10 Image 7122](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Z1dT5EWqdJMLghXN.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Z1dT5EWqdJMLghXN.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Z1dT5EWqdJMLghXN.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Z1dT5EWqdJMLghXN.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Z1dT5EWqdJMLghXN.full -->

guides.title: How to Apply Thermal Paste
guides.raw_content:
# How to Apply Thermal Paste

Application of thermal paste is essential to keep the processor cool and happy. Follow this general guide to reapply thermal paste after removing a heat sink or CPU during a repair. For more advanced directions, specific to your CPU, check out Arctic Silver's page of [link|http://www.arcticsilver.com/intel_application_method.html#|application methods].

To apply thermal paste to a phone, [link|https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+to+Apply+Thermal+Paste+to+Phones/157417|follow this guide].

## 1. Overview
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Thermal paste is responsible for conducting heat from the processor to the heat sink. Reassembling a computer without applying thermal paste will cause the processor to overheat, resulting in permanent damage.
> **Note:** Before applying a new layer of thermal paste, you must first remove any old thermal paste from both the processor surface and the heat sink.
![Step 1 Image 854666](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JPJfGyl3XRIerIU4.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JPJfGyl3XRIerIU4.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JPJfGyl3XRIerIU4.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JPJfGyl3XRIerIU4.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JPJfGyl3XRIerIU4.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Use the flat end of a spudger to scrape off as much solidified thermal paste from the copper core(s) of the heat sink as possible.
![Step 2 Image 7464](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CoewApRTPTDYnFLl.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CoewApRTPTDYnFLl.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CoewApRTPTDYnFLl.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CoewApRTPTDYnFLl.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CoewApRTPTDYnFLl.full -->
![Step 2 Image 7465](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZbPTUPJaGQktIDqv.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZbPTUPJaGQktIDqv.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZbPTUPJaGQktIDqv.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZbPTUPJaGQktIDqv.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZbPTUPJaGQktIDqv.full -->

## 3. Step 3
> **Note:** After scraping off the solidified thermal paste, a residue is still present on the copper core(s).
![Step 3 Image 7466](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oMmP4lrpTn1fsGvU.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oMmP4lrpTn1fsGvU.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oMmP4lrpTn1fsGvU.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oMmP4lrpTn1fsGvU.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oMmP4lrpTn1fsGvU.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- Use a coffee filter or a lint-free cloth and a little isopropyl alcohol (a.k.a. IPA, 90% concentration or greater)  to clean the thermal paste residue off the thermal contact surface of your heat sink.
> **Note:** Instead of IPA, you may also use a dedicated cleaning agent, such as ArctiClean Thermal Material Remover.
- Once the surface is clean, use a fresh piece of coffee filter or cloth and a little more IPA to remove any oils and prepare the surface.
- Do not touch either the chip or the heatsink, or allow any dust or debris to get on them. Even a fingerprint can be a major obstacle to thermal transfer on a chip.
- Allow the heat sink(s) to dry completely!
![Step 4 Image 7467](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/epsFyUYp1DOjNAMG.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/epsFyUYp1DOjNAMG.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/epsFyUYp1DOjNAMG.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/epsFyUYp1DOjNAMG.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/epsFyUYp1DOjNAMG.full -->
![Step 4 Image 7492](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RLVE56XCkn5M55Mw.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RLVE56XCkn5M55Mw.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RLVE56XCkn5M55Mw.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RLVE56XCkn5M55Mw.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RLVE56XCkn5M55Mw.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- Use the flat end of a plastic spudger to remove any solidified thermal paste from the surface of the processor(s).
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Do not use any metal objects for this procedure. Be careful not to break any components on the processor's surface, or get any thermal compound loose on any components (conductive pastes could cause  problems).
![Step 5 Image 7483](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5bNNPD1mBk2YZHG6.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5bNNPD1mBk2YZHG6.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5bNNPD1mBk2YZHG6.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5bNNPD1mBk2YZHG6.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5bNNPD1mBk2YZHG6.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- Again, use a coffee filter or lint-free cloth and a little IPA or ArctiClean Thermal Material Remover to clean any thermal paste residue off the processor surface.
- Use a fresh piece of coffee filter or cloth and some IPA to remove any remaining oils and prepare the surface.
- Allow the processor(s) to dry completely!
![Step 6 Image 7484](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UvbFQEffQDWhwhIn.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UvbFQEffQDWhwhIn.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UvbFQEffQDWhwhIn.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UvbFQEffQDWhwhIn.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UvbFQEffQDWhwhIn.full -->
![Step 6 Image 7493](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tNXJLnRBxsZMX3nu.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tNXJLnRBxsZMX3nu.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tNXJLnRBxsZMX3nu.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tNXJLnRBxsZMX3nu.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tNXJLnRBxsZMX3nu.full -->

## 7. Step 7
- To apply new thermal paste, [http://www.arcticsilver.com/methods.html|use the application method recommended for your specific processor type|new_window=true]—vertical line, horizontal line, middle dot, or surface spread. Note that surface spread has the potential to trap air bubbles.
- If you're using the surface spread method:
  - Wrap the tip of your index finger with a piece of plastic (such as a sandwich bag or Saran wrap).
  - Dispense a very small amount of thermal paste onto processor core(s).
  - Use your finger to gently smear the thermal paste over the entire processor core(s).
> **Note:** If you accidentally apply a small amount of thermal paste on the green surface of the processor, it will not cause any harm.
- The processor(s) is now ready for heat sink installation.
> **Note:** You do not need to apply any thermal paste on the heat sink(s), although [http://www.arcticsilver.com/methods.html|Arctic Silver gives instructions] on "tinting" the heat sink to reduce the break-in time of the thermal compound.
![Step 7 Image 7904](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6uuYpmynrisGkye5.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6uuYpmynrisGkye5.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6uuYpmynrisGkye5.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6uuYpmynrisGkye5.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6uuYpmynrisGkye5.full -->

## Conclusion

To reassemble your device, follow your device's disassembly instructions in reverse order.

guides.title: How To Solder and Desolder Connections
guides.raw_content:
# How To Solder and Desolder Connections

While many repairs can be accomplished without soldering, there are times when it's necessary to replace soldered-down components, e.g., joysticks, headphone batteries, and rumble motors. Learning how to solder opens up a new world of fun electronics projects. It may sound intimidating, but it's easy to get started!

This guide will demonstrate basic soldering skills as well as specific instructions for the following:

* [guide|750|Soldering through-hole components|stepid=4038]
* [guide|750|Desoldering through-hole components|stepid=4052]
* [guide|750|Soldering surface mount components|stepid=373590]

## 1. Safety first
> **Note:** Before you begin soldering, note the following safety precautions:
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Never solder on devices that are powered on or plugged in. Unplug, turn off, and remove power sources before soldering.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Don't solder directly to hard-shell lithium-ion batteries (such as 18650 cells). The heat from the soldering iron will damage the battery internals. Use a battery spot welder instead.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** ***Be extremely careful if you're soldering/desoldering lithium-polymer battery wires!*** You can easily short the battery with solder or your tools, resulting in battery damage and a fire hazard.  Follow these precautions:
> **Note:** ***Drain the battery below 25%.*** This reduces the battery's ability to start a fire if it was short-circuited.
> **Note:** ***Work with one wire at a time*** to avoid short circuits. Use tweezers and hold each wire to control its movement and ensure it doesn't short. If you're desoldering a battery from a circuit board, use flush cutters to ***cut each wire one-at-a-time*** to isolate the battery before you desolder the wires.
> **Note:** Whenever possible, create an indirect path by soldering connectors onto the battery and the circuit board. This reduces the chance of an unintentional short.

## 2. What's through-hole soldering?
> **Note:** [link|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Through-hole_technology|Through-hole soldering|new_window=true] refers to threading components with leads ''through holes'' on a circuit board, then securing them with molten solder. Through-hole soldering is prevalent in DIY projects and modern electronics, where it's used to secure large components (such as capacitors and ports).
> **Note:** Common through-hole components include joystick modules, ports, capacitors, microcontrollers, batteries, and wires.

## 3. How to solder through-hole components
> **Note:** The next 10 steps will show you how to solder through-hole components onto a circuit board. In addition to a soldering iron, you'll need:
  - A vise, clamp, or "[product|IF145-082|helping hands|new_window=true]" tool. If you're joining two wires, our [product|IF145-532|Soldering Splint|new_window=true] is a great tool.
  - A pair of [product|IF145-125|safety glasses|new_window=true] (eyeglasses will protect your eyes, but solder spatter will damage the glasses).
  - Rosin-core solder wire ([product|IF317-058|leaded|new_window=true] or [product|IF145-077-2|lead-free|new_window=true])
  - A tip cleaning tool (wet sponge or [product|IF317-032|brass wire|new_window=true])
  - A [guide|170836|fume extractor|new_window=true] (if you're working indoors)
  - High concentration (>90%) isopropyl alcohol and a [product|IF145-062|soft bristle brush|new_window=true] (like a toothbrush)
  - A [product|IF145-002-2|spudger|new_window=true], [product|IF145-020|tweezers|new_window=true], and [product|IF317-039|flush cutters|new_window=true]

## 4. Step 4
- [product|IF145-494|Set up your tools|new_window=true] in a well-lit area, away from anything flammable.
- Secure the circuit board with a vise or a "helping hands" tool. Angle the board such that you can easily access the solder pads.
- Place the fume extractor close to the project so it'll catch the solder fumes.
- Wear your safety goggles.
![Step 4 Image 3419465](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oFeWHKdNCJcNLSCZ.full)

## 5. Step 5
- Thread the component leads through the circuit board holes. Most components should lie flat, close to the board.
> **Note:** ***Double-check the orientation*** if the component is electrically directional (such as diodes, LEDs, and electrolytic capacitors).
> **Note:** Diodes normally have a bar indicating the cathode (-). LEDs have a shorter lead on the cathode (-) and a flat spot on the dome.

## 6. Step 6
- Bend the leads out slightly to help keep the component in place. Alternatively, you can use painter's tape to secure the component.

## 7. Intermediate Guide
- Turn on your [product|IF145-495|soldering iron|new_window=true]. If your soldering iron has temperature control:
  - Set it to 300 °C (~570 °F) if you're using ***leaded solder***
  - Set it to 375 °C (~700 °F) if you're using ***lead-free solder***
- Clean the tip of your soldering iron. If you're using a sponge, wet the sponge and quickly wipe the tip across it. If you're using brass wire, stab the tip into the wire a few times.
![Step 7 Image 3419466](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wQgGfIEMQbQXGXS5.full)

## 8. Step 8
- Melt a small glob of solder onto the tip of the iron. This is called "tinning the tip" and will help with heat transfer.
> **Note:** You'll likely see some wispy smoke as you melt solder. This is mostly the ''rosin-core flux'' that's built into the solder wire. Flux helps molten solder flow, but gets vaporized over time. Once that happens, you'll need to either melt more solder to refresh the flux, or apply flux from an [product|IF317-056|external source|new_window=true].
> **Note:** If this is your first time using a soldering iron, repeat the cleaning and melting procedure a few times to get a feel at how molten solder handles and how much solder the tip can hold.
![Step 8 Image 3419476](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UHTMhHXlveK4pRCY.full)

![Step 8 Image 3419477](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WygEZbsNALnbJckg.full)

## 9. Step 9
> **Note:** You're going to heat the solder pad and the component lead ***very hot for 2 to 3 seconds***. The pad and lead should readily melt the solder wire.
- Press the tip against the circuit board's solder pad and the component lead for about 1 second to heat them both. Angle the tip so it has maximum contact with the pad and lead.
> **Note:** If you're using a narrow soldering tip or working with a large solder pad, you may not be able to transfer enough heat to the area. You can try increasing the temperature by 50°C or switch to a larger tip for more effective heat transfer.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** If you heat the circuit board continuously for more than 10 seconds, the excessive heat may damage the solder pad or component. Additionally, it could start loosening adjacent components.
- Feed the solder wire into the heated area until there's a concave pool of solder surrounding the lead.
> **Note:** This should happen within a few seconds. If the solder doesn't adhere to the pad, apply flux to the pad or increase the temperature.
> **Note:** Don't feed the solder directly onto the tip as it won't flow properly into the pad and lead causing a weak connection.
- Remove the solder wire, then remove the soldering iron from the solder pad.
![Step 9 Image 3419480](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Tuv5C5XZiglCHQGP.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Tuv5C5XZiglCHQGP.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Tuv5C5XZiglCHQGP.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Tuv5C5XZiglCHQGP.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Tuv5C5XZiglCHQGP.full -->

## 10. Step 10
- Congratulations—you've created a solder joint! Inspect the joint to see if it formed correctly:
  - ***Leaded solder joints*** should look like a shiny, concave tent surrounding the entire lead.
> **Note:** If the joint isn't shiny, it may not have formed correctly. Reheat the joint briefly and allow it to cool.
  - ***Lead-free solder joints*** should look like a concave tent surrounding the entire lead. They may be shiny or dull.
> **Note:** If the solder joint doesn't surround the entire lead, reheat the joint and add more solder.
> **Note:** If the solder looks like a round bead instead of a concave tent, it didn't bond to the component lead. Reheat the joint and try to get the lead hot enough so the solder bonds to it.
> **Note:** Check if any solder unintentionally bridged with a different joint. If so, apply some flux and reheat one of the joints to carefully break the bridge. If the bridge doesn't want to separate follow [guide|173873|this step|stepid=370680] and use solder wick to pull away any extra solder.
> **Note:** Like any skill, practice makes perfect. If your first solder joint doesn't look picture-perfect, that's OK! It takes a few attempts to get the hang of the movement and timing.

## 11. Clean up your project
- Once you've finished soldering all of your leads, use a flush cutter to trim the leads right above the solder joint.
- ***Leave a glob of solder on the tip (tin the tip) before you turn the iron off.*** If you're using rosin-core solder, wait till the tip stops smoking. The solder glob protects the tip from getting dirty or oxidized, increasing its longevity.

## 12. Step 12
- Apply some isopropyl alcohol to the solder joints and scrub the area with a soft-bristled brush to remove any flux residue.
- Wipe the solder joint with a lint-free cloth to soak up the flux and alcohol residue.

## 13. Through-hole soldering tips and tricks
> **Note:** If you're soldering a component with multiple through-hole leads (such as a joystick module, microcontroller, or port), solder two opposite leads to hold the component position in place. Check the alignment, then solder the remaining joints.
> **Note:** Alternatively, you can bend two opposite leads to secure the component to the board while you solder.
> **Note:** If the molten solder doesn't flow or is hard to manipulate, apply more flux to the joint.
![Step 13 Image 3419482](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/44cBSKJNVFmFoROV.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/44cBSKJNVFmFoROV.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/44cBSKJNVFmFoROV.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/44cBSKJNVFmFoROV.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/44cBSKJNVFmFoROV.full -->

## 14. How to desolder through-hole components
> **Note:** The next 8 steps will show you how to desolder through-hole components using a solder wick and desoldering pump.
> **Note:** If you're new to soldering, be sure to read the soldering steps above first, as this builds upon that knowlege.
> **Note:** In addition to the soldering equipment, you'll need:
  - [product|IF317-053|Solder wick|new_window=true] (aka desoldering braid) and/or a [product|IF145-473|desoldering pump|new_window=true].
  - [product|IF317-056|Flux|new_window=true]
  - A spudger, tweezers, and/or pliers (to help loosen stubborn components)
![Step 14 Image 3390917](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PTfa3hW1smJmhG21.full)

## 15. Step 15
- Secure the circuit board with a vise or a "helping hands" tool. Angle the board such that you can easily access the solder pads. Wear safety goggles.
- If possible, use a tip with the largest surface area that can still fit between the solder joint.
- Turn on your soldering iron. If your soldering iron has temperature control:
  - Set it to 350 °C (~650 °F) if you're using ***leaded solder***
  - Set it to 375 °C (~700 °F) if you're using ***lead-free solder***
![Step 15 Image 3390918](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UYCH6BO4ktCE5iHU.full)

## 16. Step 16
- Clean the tip of your soldering iron. If you're using a sponge, wet the sponge and quickly wipe the tip across it. If you're using brass wire, stab the tip into the wire a few times.
- Melt a small glob of solder onto the tip. This will help with heat transfer.
> **Note:** If you're desoldering with a ***solder wick***, proceed to the next step.
> **Note:** If you're desoldering with a ***desoldering pump***, skip to [guide|173873|this step|stepid=370734].

## 17. How to desolder using a solder wick
> **Note:** You're going to melt the solder joint ''through the wick'', allowing the wick to draw the molten solder into itself.
- Apply a bead of [product|IF317-056|flux|new_window=true] to the solder joint.
- Place a clean portion of the solder wick on top of the solder joint.
- Press the soldering iron tip firmly against the wick for 2-3 seconds. You're trying to heat the wick hot enough so that it melts the solder underneath it.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** If you heat the circuit board continuously for more than 10 seconds, the excessive heat may damage the solder pad.
> **Note:** If the wick doesn't draw solder, you may need to increase the temperature. The wick may also be oxidized due to age—apply more flux or try a newer roll of wick.
- As the solder saturates the wick, slide the wick so that a new portion touches the joint. You'll know it's saturated when the wick's color changes from copper to silver.
- Once most of the solder has soaked into the wick, lift the wick and tip away together from the joint.

## 18. Step 18
- Use tweezers to grip the component and remove it.
> **Note:** If the leads are stuck but don't have a lot of residual solder, heat the solder pad directly and use tweezers or a spudger to gently remove it.
> **Note:** If there is still a lot of solder left on the pad, apply more flux and try using the wick again.
- Use flush cutters to remove your used wick.
- When you're done desoldering, refer to [guide|173873|this step|stepid=371193] to clean up your board.

## 19. How to desolder using a desoldering pump
> **Note:** To desolder with a desoldering pump, you're going to heat the solder joint and use the pump to suck up the molten solder.
> **Note:** If this is your first time using a desoldering pump, [guide|142538|check out this guide|new_window=true].
- Depress the desoldering pump plunger until it locks in place.

## 20. Step 20
- Press the soldering iron tip against the solder joint.
- Once the solder melts, position the pump nozzle as close to the molten solder as possible without touching the tip.
> **Note:** The nozzle is made of heat-resistant plastic, so don't worry if you occasionally brush the tip with it.
- Press the side button to activate the pump and suck up the molten solder.

## 22. Through-hole desoldering tips and tricks
> **Note:** If your desoldering pump doesn't remove all the solder and you're having trouble heating the joint, apply some more solder and try again.
> **Note:** If you're still having trouble melting the solder, apply some [product|IF317-061|low‑temp solder|new_window=true] to the joint to keep it liquid for longer.
> **Note:** Clean your soldering iron before use to avoid brittle joints from mixing low‑temp solder with standard solder.
> **Note:** Are you desoldering a lot of pins? Or do you just desolder a lot? A dedicated desoldering station or [product|IF317-010|gun|new_window=true] is a worthwhile investment.

## 23. What's surface-mount soldering?
> **Note:** [link|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surface-mount_technology|Surface-mount soldering|new_window=true] is a process where components are soldered onto the surface of the circuit board. Most electronics manufacturers use surface-mount technology (SMT) because it can be automated and is more cost-effective.
> **Note:** In industrial manufacturing, a machine uses a stencil to lay down solder paste onto the circuit board. Robotic arms precisely [link|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pick-and-place_machine|pick and place|new_window=true] each component onto the board. The board passes through an oven, where the solder paste melts and solders the components to the board.
> **Note:** Surface mount components are significantly smaller than through-hole components, making them difficult to solder by hand. But with a bit of patience, practice, and a good magnifying glass, you can become proficient in surface-mount soldering!

## 24. How to solder surface-mount components
- The next 6 steps will show you how to solder surface-mount components onto a circuit board. You'll need a fine-tipped soldering iron in addition to the following:
  - Solder wire ([product|IF317-058|leaded|new_window=true] or [product|IF145-077-2|lead-free|new_window=true]) or solder paste
  - [product|IF317-056|Flux|new_window=true]
  - [product|IF317-047|Tweezers|new_window=true] and [product|IF145-059|picks|new_window=true] to help manipulate the tiny components
  - A tip cleaning tool (wet sponge or [product|IF317-032|brass wire|new_window=true])
  - A magnifying glass or lens
  - A [guide|170836|fume extractor|new_window=true] (if you're working indoors)
  - High concentration (>90%) isopropyl alcohol and a [product|IF145-062|soft bristle brush|new_window=true] (like a toothbrush)
![Step 24 Image 3419526](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/I5cnWfTCPlvAYaiE.full)

## 25. Step 25
- Set up your tools in a well-lit area, away from anything flammable.
- Set the circuit board on a flat, non-flammable, heat-resistant surface or secure it with helping hands or a [product|IF317-033|PCB vise|new_window=true].
- Place the fume extractor close to the project so that it'll catch the solder fumes.
- Wear your safety goggles.

## 26. Step 26
- Apply a small bead of flux onto each solder pad.
> **Note:** If you're using solder paste, apply a small amount of paste instead. Most solder pastes contain flux.
- Use tweezers and picks to carefully maneuver your component so that it straddles between the solder pads.
> **Note:** This can be very tricky depending on the size of your component! Take your time and don't press against the component too hard, or you may fling it out of place.
> **Note:** ***Double-check the component orientation*** if it's electrically directional (such as LEDs and diodes). These components normally have a bar indicating the cathode (-) end.

## 27. Step 27
- Turn on your soldering iron. If your soldering iron has temperature control:
  - Set it to 350 °C (~650 °F) if you're using ***leaded solder***
  - Set it to 400 °C (~750 °F) if you're using ***lead-free solder***
- Clean the tip of your soldering iron. If you're using a sponge, wet the sponge and quickly wipe the tip across it. If you're using brass wire, stab the tip into the wire a few times.
- If you're ''not'' using solder paste, melt a small amount of solder onto the tip. You'll transfer this solder onto the joint.
![Step 27 Image 3419507](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hVBy6Nkcd3BgcJrt.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hVBy6Nkcd3BgcJrt.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hVBy6Nkcd3BgcJrt.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hVBy6Nkcd3BgcJrt.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/hVBy6Nkcd3BgcJrt.full -->
![Step 27 Image 3442255](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kxwFFx6NeTECKtFg.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kxwFFx6NeTECKtFg.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kxwFFx6NeTECKtFg.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kxwFFx6NeTECKtFg.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kxwFFx6NeTECKtFg.full -->
![Step 27 Image 3419509](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dKcekFiDW14Vok5u.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dKcekFiDW14Vok5u.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dKcekFiDW14Vok5u.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dKcekFiDW14Vok5u.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dKcekFiDW14Vok5u.full -->

## 28. Step 28
- Carefully press a tweezer point or the tip of a spudger on top of the component to hold it in place.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** The soldering iron will spill a lot of heat around the point of contact, which can easily loosen surrounding components. Be careful not to bump the surrounding parts with your tools.
- Touch the soldering iron tip to the solder pad and the component. Once the pad heats up, it will draw the molten solder onto itself.
> **Note:** This should happen within a few seconds. If the solder doesn't adhere to the pad, apply more flux to the pad or increase the temperature.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Don't heat continuously more than 10 seconds at a time, or the heat may damage the component and solder pad. Allow the circuit board to cool down, then try again.
- Remove the tip from the solder joint.
- Repeat this process for the rest of the component leads.
![Step 28 Image 3419512](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wD6CFSCHv4jJCIhk.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wD6CFSCHv4jJCIhk.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wD6CFSCHv4jJCIhk.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wD6CFSCHv4jJCIhk.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wD6CFSCHv4jJCIhk.full -->
![Step 28 Image 3419511](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rN3GpIkXansVETME.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rN3GpIkXansVETME.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rN3GpIkXansVETME.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rN3GpIkXansVETME.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rN3GpIkXansVETME.full -->
![Step 28 Image 3419510](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/btoJ55GmZWBcXhXT.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/btoJ55GmZWBcXhXT.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/btoJ55GmZWBcXhXT.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/btoJ55GmZWBcXhXT.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/btoJ55GmZWBcXhXT.full -->

## 29. How to clean
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Be gentle when you're cleaning small components as they can easily break off the board.
- Apply some isopropyl alcohol to the solder joints and scrub the area with a soft bristled brush to remove any flux residue.
- Wipe the solder joint with a lint-free cloth to soak up the flux and alcohol residue.
![Step 29 Image 3390954](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2xFaXVAM3O4rtjpw.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2xFaXVAM3O4rtjpw.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2xFaXVAM3O4rtjpw.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2xFaXVAM3O4rtjpw.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2xFaXVAM3O4rtjpw.full -->
![Step 29 Image 3390955](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Th2eQuNgeR2tWb6W.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Th2eQuNgeR2tWb6W.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Th2eQuNgeR2tWb6W.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Th2eQuNgeR2tWb6W.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Th2eQuNgeR2tWb6W.full -->
![Step 29 Image 3390956](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/j4I1N1G5wLkbGMDB.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/j4I1N1G5wLkbGMDB.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/j4I1N1G5wLkbGMDB.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/j4I1N1G5wLkbGMDB.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/j4I1N1G5wLkbGMDB.full -->

## 30. Surface mount tips and tricks
> **Note:** Many surface mount components (especially integrated circuits) have multiple leads that need to be soldered. They can be difficult to align and secure to the board:
  - Hold the component in place and solder the corner leads to secure it in place.
  - Alternatively, you can secure the component to the board using [product|IF145-113|polyimide tape|new_window=true] and then solder the corner leads.
![Step 30 Image 3419513](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jvhBQCwqybnvMWgb.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jvhBQCwqybnvMWgb.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jvhBQCwqybnvMWgb.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jvhBQCwqybnvMWgb.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jvhBQCwqybnvMWgb.full -->
![Step 30 Image 3419514](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YopteTeCYMRLgPls.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YopteTeCYMRLgPls.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YopteTeCYMRLgPls.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YopteTeCYMRLgPls.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YopteTeCYMRLgPls.full -->

## Conclusion

Congratulations on completing this introductory soldering guide! You've taken the first step toward mastering a valuable and versatile skill. With the basics under your belt, you're well-equipped to tackle various electronics projects and repairs. Remember, practice makes perfect, so don't hesitate to experiment and refine your techniques.

For more soldering information, [[Topic:Soldering|click here|new_window=true]].

guides.title: How to Install macOS High Sierra
guides.raw_content:
# How to Install macOS High Sierra

***Note***: If you’re trying to install the latest MacOS on a 2009 and later Apple computer, follow the [guide|119499|MacOS internet recovery guide instead].

If you have recently upgraded or replaced the hard drive for your MacBook or iMac, you will need to reinstall macOS onto it. This guide will show you how to install macOS High Sierra onto a blank hard drive by using a bootable flash drive.

***Before you begin, you will need to create a bootable flash drive.*** This requires having access to a Mac currently running High Sierra, in order to download the 7.7 GB High Sierra file in the App Store. You will also need an empty flash drive that can fit 5.4 GB.

[guide|66371|Follow this guide to create a bootable macOS High Sierra flash drive|new_window=true] before proceeding with the guide.

## 1. Step 1
- With the device powered off, disconnect any external hard drives and flash drives.
- Plug in your [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/Create+a+bootable+USB+drive/66371|macOS High Sierra bootable flash drive].
- Hold down the '''[option]''' or '''[alt] (⌥)''' key on the keyboard and power on the device.
- When you see the boot selection screen as shown, release the '''[option]''' key.
- Use either the keyboard's arrow keys or the mouse to select "Install MacOS High Sierra." Press '''[enter]''' or click your selection with the mouse.
![Step 1 Image 1450956](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5dNlKcdAB4ONfx2f.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5dNlKcdAB4ONfx2f.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5dNlKcdAB4ONfx2f.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5dNlKcdAB4ONfx2f.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5dNlKcdAB4ONfx2f.full -->
![Step 1 Image 1450957](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Uh1RXprxZ1RICqyd.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Uh1RXprxZ1RICqyd.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Uh1RXprxZ1RICqyd.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Uh1RXprxZ1RICqyd.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Uh1RXprxZ1RICqyd.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Your Mac will begin copying the installation files from the flash drive. This may take up to 30 minutes.
> **Note:** Depending on the speed of your flash drive, it may look like progress has frozen, but it should resume if you continue to wait.
- When prompted, select your language and press '''[enter]''', or click the arrow button.
![Step 2 Image 1450958](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/KLWkIDKrnMclhOEK.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/KLWkIDKrnMclhOEK.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/KLWkIDKrnMclhOEK.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/KLWkIDKrnMclhOEK.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/KLWkIDKrnMclhOEK.full -->
![Step 2 Image 1450959](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HqYwQmWRsOjVNNH1.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HqYwQmWRsOjVNNH1.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HqYwQmWRsOjVNNH1.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HqYwQmWRsOjVNNH1.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HqYwQmWRsOjVNNH1.full -->

## 3. Step 3
> **Note:** If you don't need to pre-configure your hard drive, skip to step 5. If you're not sure or if the drive is used, it's a good idea to pre-configure your hard drive.
- Select "Disk Utility" from the menu and press '''[enter]''' or click the continue button.
![Step 3 Image 1450960](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/DCuNO5hDiGNaCmLG.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/DCuNO5hDiGNaCmLG.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/DCuNO5hDiGNaCmLG.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/DCuNO5hDiGNaCmLG.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/DCuNO5hDiGNaCmLG.full -->
![Step 3 Image 1450961](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2OCEict6yKIlqpWb.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2OCEict6yKIlqpWb.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2OCEict6yKIlqpWb.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2OCEict6yKIlqpWb.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2OCEict6yKIlqpWb.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- Select your hard drive from the left column in Disk Utility.
> **Note:** It is most likely the uninitialized drive.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** If you have multiple hard drives, make sure you select the correct one as the next step will wipe the selected drive clean.
  - Click the "Erase" button at the top of the window.
  - Choose a name for your drive (you can rename it later). Leave the scheme as '''GUID Partition Map'''.
  - If you are installing an SSD, choose the '''APFS''' format. If you are installing a mechanical drive or if your device doesn't officially support the newer OS, leave the format as '''Mac OS Extended (journaled)'''
  - Click "Erase." When the process completes, click "Done."
  - Exit the Disk Utility by clicking on the red X button on the top left corner of the window.
![Step 4 Image 1450966](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SSqoTYYhQnxkZWAE.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SSqoTYYhQnxkZWAE.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SSqoTYYhQnxkZWAE.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SSqoTYYhQnxkZWAE.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SSqoTYYhQnxkZWAE.full -->
![Step 4 Image 1450967](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BpqX5AeALjIGJmyQ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BpqX5AeALjIGJmyQ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BpqX5AeALjIGJmyQ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BpqX5AeALjIGJmyQ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BpqX5AeALjIGJmyQ.full -->
![Step 4 Image 1450968](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FMcPJ36jcbkNBoVY.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FMcPJ36jcbkNBoVY.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FMcPJ36jcbkNBoVY.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FMcPJ36jcbkNBoVY.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FMcPJ36jcbkNBoVY.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- Select "Reinstall macOS" from the menu and press '''[enter]''' or click "Continue."
![Step 5 Image 1450970](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ske134IAlQpT5Waf.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ske134IAlQpT5Waf.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ske134IAlQpT5Waf.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ske134IAlQpT5Waf.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ske134IAlQpT5Waf.full -->
![Step 5 Image 1450971](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ohHxW1xIOC3CmnCm.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ohHxW1xIOC3CmnCm.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ohHxW1xIOC3CmnCm.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ohHxW1xIOC3CmnCm.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ohHxW1xIOC3CmnCm.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- Read through the license agreement.
- Click "Agree" to accept the license agreement.
- Your Mac will now install macOS High Sierra. Be patient and wait for it to complete.
- Once the install is complete, the device will restart itself.
![Step 6 Image 1450972](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGuRjID2HKhj51AR.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGuRjID2HKhj51AR.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGuRjID2HKhj51AR.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGuRjID2HKhj51AR.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGuRjID2HKhj51AR.full -->
![Step 6 Image 1450973](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CNHDiRuPX4L1DFCF.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CNHDiRuPX4L1DFCF.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CNHDiRuPX4L1DFCF.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CNHDiRuPX4L1DFCF.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CNHDiRuPX4L1DFCF.full -->
![Step 6 Image 1450974](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QcXBwxHMwtUkQcAu.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QcXBwxHMwtUkQcAu.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QcXBwxHMwtUkQcAu.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QcXBwxHMwtUkQcAu.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QcXBwxHMwtUkQcAu.full -->

## Conclusion

High Sierra should now be freshly installed! Enjoy!

guides.title: How to Create a Teardown
guides.raw_content:
# How to Create a Teardown

Create teardowns for fun! For more information about writing teardown guides, check out our how to take [guide|718|awesome photos guide] and the [[Info:Teardown_FAQ|Teardown FAQ]]. You can also take a look at our [[Info:Teardown|Teardown Guidelines]] to get ideas on how to write an awesome teardown!

## 1. Step 1
- To begin, decide what you want to take apart.  Some examples of things '''not''' to take apart include:
  - Your pet poodle.
  - Grandpa's pacemaker.
  - Any device containing plutonium.
  - Optimus Prime.
- Next, make your way to the store to pick up your new device.  We prefer eco-friendly leg power, but to each their own.
- Enter the store to find what you are looking for.  If necessary, camp outside the store to be the first in line.
![Step 1 Image 8459](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/khWp63IhFNfsYsrF.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/khWp63IhFNfsYsrF.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/khWp63IhFNfsYsrF.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/khWp63IhFNfsYsrF.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/khWp63IhFNfsYsrF.full -->
![Step 1 Image 8451](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mryhBFqVvj6TwPvg.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mryhBFqVvj6TwPvg.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mryhBFqVvj6TwPvg.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mryhBFqVvj6TwPvg.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mryhBFqVvj6TwPvg.full -->
![Step 1 Image 8447](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NUqn2vY4GVBsQx2Q.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NUqn2vY4GVBsQx2Q.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NUqn2vY4GVBsQx2Q.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NUqn2vY4GVBsQx2Q.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NUqn2vY4GVBsQx2Q.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Next, find your device of choice in the store.  Try not to tackle the 70 year-old woman who just took the last one off the shelf.
- Don't forget to pay for the product. Contrary to popular belief, Jedi mind tricks do not work on security guards.
- Politely decline the extended warranty.
![Step 2 Image 8444](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PvQkpsNBYcPbENKj.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PvQkpsNBYcPbENKj.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PvQkpsNBYcPbENKj.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PvQkpsNBYcPbENKj.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PvQkpsNBYcPbENKj.full -->
![Step 2 Image 8470](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gLphVEWZAhTHlOsj.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gLphVEWZAhTHlOsj.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gLphVEWZAhTHlOsj.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gLphVEWZAhTHlOsj.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gLphVEWZAhTHlOsj.full -->
![Step 2 Image 8469](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NDJROWKa6gCfmXGm.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NDJROWKa6gCfmXGm.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NDJROWKa6gCfmXGm.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NDJROWKa6gCfmXGm.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NDJROWKa6gCfmXGm.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- Now that you're safely home, unbox your new beauty and bask in its technological superiority.  If you watch closely enough, you can witness your device depreciating.
- Don't forget to pretend to read the instruction manual before throwing it away.
- With your new device up and running, its time to actually enjoy your new purchase.  Remember: water + electronics = shattered dreams.
![Step 3 Image 8452](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VIMYKehZdYUmhnMq.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VIMYKehZdYUmhnMq.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VIMYKehZdYUmhnMq.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VIMYKehZdYUmhnMq.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VIMYKehZdYUmhnMq.full -->
![Step 3 Image 8453](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/npLOwhfVqBYdiGXV.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/npLOwhfVqBYdiGXV.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/npLOwhfVqBYdiGXV.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/npLOwhfVqBYdiGXV.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/npLOwhfVqBYdiGXV.full -->
![Step 3 Image 8457](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Xr2SYywBCQGUUnDc.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Xr2SYywBCQGUUnDc.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Xr2SYywBCQGUUnDc.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Xr2SYywBCQGUUnDc.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Xr2SYywBCQGUUnDc.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- Make sure to keep track of all the appropriate tools.
- Use extreme caution when disassembling the device, unless your intention is to show the destruction of a device. In that case, proceed as planned.
- Most important of all, make sure to have fun!
![Step 4 Image 8460](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EnJ4qQmxQwivZNWk.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EnJ4qQmxQwivZNWk.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EnJ4qQmxQwivZNWk.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EnJ4qQmxQwivZNWk.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EnJ4qQmxQwivZNWk.full -->
![Step 4 Image 8468](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MWCvRTiihXvBcXwH.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MWCvRTiihXvBcXwH.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MWCvRTiihXvBcXwH.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MWCvRTiihXvBcXwH.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MWCvRTiihXvBcXwH.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- It's now time to setup the photo room environment.
- Lighting is essential for good photographs. Set up lamps and focus the light near your work area.
- We recommend attaching a portable lamp to a tripod to aid in precisely focusing light.
![Step 5 Image 8465](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pqRUUIyf1O23DaFt.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pqRUUIyf1O23DaFt.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pqRUUIyf1O23DaFt.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pqRUUIyf1O23DaFt.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pqRUUIyf1O23DaFt.full -->
![Step 5 Image 8471](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PZdGHU5xHwPnBPCT.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PZdGHU5xHwPnBPCT.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PZdGHU5xHwPnBPCT.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PZdGHU5xHwPnBPCT.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PZdGHU5xHwPnBPCT.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- With all the proper equipment set up, you can now move on to the actual disassembly of the device.
- During disassembly, document all your steps with notes and pictures to share your knowledge with the iFixit community.
- You can place a sheet of white paper beneath your workspace for better pictures.
> **Note:** Included is a teardown shot taken under our professional lighting setup. Actual results may vary.
![Step 6 Image 8463](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eMeTORjfxiPuEBoI.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eMeTORjfxiPuEBoI.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eMeTORjfxiPuEBoI.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eMeTORjfxiPuEBoI.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eMeTORjfxiPuEBoI.full -->
![Step 6 Image 8467](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqoYrbT5t14P2O1Z.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqoYrbT5t14P2O1Z.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqoYrbT5t14P2O1Z.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqoYrbT5t14P2O1Z.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqoYrbT5t14P2O1Z.full -->
![Step 6 Image 8474](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ILWjtTQEOVHvwmO4.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ILWjtTQEOVHvwmO4.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ILWjtTQEOVHvwmO4.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ILWjtTQEOVHvwmO4.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ILWjtTQEOVHvwmO4.full -->

## 7. Step 7
- Now it's time to share your knowledge with the world by indulging in one of the most honored traditions of all time: writing.
- Invoke your imagination and unleash your writing ability upon the iFixit community.
![Step 7 Image 8461](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IEjPZcu6AxFtUgcv.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IEjPZcu6AxFtUgcv.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IEjPZcu6AxFtUgcv.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IEjPZcu6AxFtUgcv.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IEjPZcu6AxFtUgcv.full -->

## 8. Step 8
- Now that your work is published on [link|http://www.ifixit.com|iFixit], it's time to sit back and relax and enjoy the sweet satisfaction of having created a teardown guide.
- This calls for an iPod dance party!
![Step 8 Image 8443](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CqylbExU3eTkuEnc.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CqylbExU3eTkuEnc.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CqylbExU3eTkuEnc.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CqylbExU3eTkuEnc.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CqylbExU3eTkuEnc.full -->

## Conclusion

Great job! You made a teardown! But why stop there?
[https://www.ifixit.com/Answers|Help answer questions!]

guides.title: Banana Teardown
guides.raw_content:
# Banana Teardown

In this teardown, we open a banana to see what's inside.  Yellow and delicious, but most importantly, yellow.

## 1. Step 1
- Take one banana from the bunch.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Don't squeeze too hard!
![Step 1 Image 8961](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ma2srJJhFukFZqnY.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ma2srJJhFukFZqnY.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ma2srJJhFukFZqnY.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ma2srJJhFukFZqnY.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ma2srJJhFukFZqnY.full -->
![Step 1 Image 8967](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QlgIemJkxpVCKBJC.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QlgIemJkxpVCKBJC.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QlgIemJkxpVCKBJC.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QlgIemJkxpVCKBJC.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QlgIemJkxpVCKBJC.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Hold the banana in your left hand and grip the stem between your right thumb and forefinger.
![Step 2 Image 8968](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AccRAcWkPglGvHmR.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AccRAcWkPglGvHmR.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AccRAcWkPglGvHmR.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AccRAcWkPglGvHmR.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AccRAcWkPglGvHmR.full -->
![Step 2 Image 8954](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iEWaSBWPYm3tYjpg.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iEWaSBWPYm3tYjpg.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iEWaSBWPYm3tYjpg.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iEWaSBWPYm3tYjpg.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iEWaSBWPYm3tYjpg.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- Pull the stem downward until the peel splits.
![Step 3 Image 8972](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5HbDNEZIEUBvhThP.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5HbDNEZIEUBvhThP.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5HbDNEZIEUBvhThP.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5HbDNEZIEUBvhThP.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5HbDNEZIEUBvhThP.full -->
![Step 3 Image 8963](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Hcpb3wpDpVF36Sxu.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Hcpb3wpDpVF36Sxu.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Hcpb3wpDpVF36Sxu.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Hcpb3wpDpVF36Sxu.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Hcpb3wpDpVF36Sxu.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- Insert your thumbs into the split of the peel and pull the two sides apart.
- Expose the top of the banana.  It may be slightly squished from pulling on the stem, but this will not affect the flavor.
![Step 4 Image 8952](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kUuqk6IOCkBhJOKp.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kUuqk6IOCkBhJOKp.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kUuqk6IOCkBhJOKp.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kUuqk6IOCkBhJOKp.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kUuqk6IOCkBhJOKp.full -->
![Step 4 Image 8956](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PEdiDbyVQT6G1BwO.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PEdiDbyVQT6G1BwO.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PEdiDbyVQT6G1BwO.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PEdiDbyVQT6G1BwO.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PEdiDbyVQT6G1BwO.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- Pull open the peel, starting from your original split, and opening it along the length of the banana.
![Step 5 Image 8970](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OtEwPF6vVZpArJ4R.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OtEwPF6vVZpArJ4R.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OtEwPF6vVZpArJ4R.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OtEwPF6vVZpArJ4R.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OtEwPF6vVZpArJ4R.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- Remove fruit from peel.
![Step 6 Image 8962](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gupWBYpZV43dd2Vh.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gupWBYpZV43dd2Vh.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gupWBYpZV43dd2Vh.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gupWBYpZV43dd2Vh.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gupWBYpZV43dd2Vh.full -->
![Step 6 Image 8953](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EWtuJRfjyvvfogv3.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EWtuJRfjyvvfogv3.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EWtuJRfjyvvfogv3.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EWtuJRfjyvvfogv3.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EWtuJRfjyvvfogv3.full -->

## 7. Step 7
- Eat and enjoy!
> **Note:** This is where you'll need your teeth.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Do not choke on banana!
![Step 7 Image 8959](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lPt2dJrcVZe4XApM.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lPt2dJrcVZe4XApM.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lPt2dJrcVZe4XApM.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lPt2dJrcVZe4XApM.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lPt2dJrcVZe4XApM.full -->
![Step 7 Image 8969](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/V5CAEebHaYIJUcmE.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/V5CAEebHaYIJUcmE.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/V5CAEebHaYIJUcmE.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/V5CAEebHaYIJUcmE.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/V5CAEebHaYIJUcmE.full -->

guides.title: Testing Power Cord Continuity
guides.raw_content:
# Testing Power Cord Continuity

A detailed guide on how to use a continuity tester to check for adequate electrical connection on a power cord.

## 1. Set the multimeter to continuity test mode
> ⚠️ **Caution:** ***Unplug the power cord*** from the device and from the AC outlet. Failure to do so can result in electrical shock or death.
- ***Set the multimeter to continuity*** test mode.
> **Note:** The setting is symbolized by a diode or sound wave symbol as seen in the pictures. If the meter is set to the correct mode, you should hear the meter beep when the leads are touched together.
- Verify that the positive lead is plugged to the voltmeter/ ohmmeter outlet.
![Step 1 Image 2466275](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1GrSMJdoXyKGhcyn.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1GrSMJdoXyKGhcyn.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1GrSMJdoXyKGhcyn.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1GrSMJdoXyKGhcyn.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1GrSMJdoXyKGhcyn.full -->
![Step 1 Image 2465521](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/P53MrRF2XDHPPC5Z.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/P53MrRF2XDHPPC5Z.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/P53MrRF2XDHPPC5Z.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/P53MrRF2XDHPPC5Z.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/P53MrRF2XDHPPC5Z.full -->

## 2. Test for a break in the cable
- ***Test for a potential open circuit*** by using one multimeter lead to touch one of the prongs on the AC side of power cord. Use the other lead to touch one end of the console side of the power cord.
> **Note:** If there is an adequate electrical connection, the multimeter will continuously beep. A short beep does not mean that there is continuity. If it does not beep the first time, try using the lead to touch the other prong.
- ***Repeat the above directions*** in step 2 for the other outlet and prong of the power cord.
> **Note:** If the multimeter fails to beep on any of the occasions outlined above, your power cord is [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-circuit_voltage|open]. In other words, you will need to replace the power cable.
![Step 2 Image 23356](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2SosQFhUjQpCFpgk.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2SosQFhUjQpCFpgk.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2SosQFhUjQpCFpgk.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2SosQFhUjQpCFpgk.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2SosQFhUjQpCFpgk.full -->

## 3. Test for a short
> **Note:** Once you have verified that the power cord provides an adequate electrical connection, you will have to test that the cable is not [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short_circuit|shorted].
- '''Test for a potential short circuit''' by touching each prong on the AC side of the power cord.
> **Note:** If the multimeter beeps, your power cord is bad and must be replaced immediately.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** If your power cord is shorted, do not attempt to replug the cord into the AC outlet.
- If your power cord has passed all of the steps above, then you have successfully tested that your power cord is in working order.
![Step 3 Image 24218](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/noSb2qdZfcOIB5PT.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/noSb2qdZfcOIB5PT.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/noSb2qdZfcOIB5PT.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/noSb2qdZfcOIB5PT.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/noSb2qdZfcOIB5PT.full -->
