guides.title: Constructing a Capacitor Discharge Tool
guides.raw_content:
# Constructing a Capacitor Discharge Tool

[link|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capacitor|Capacitors] are electronic components found in almost every device containing a circuit board. Large capacitors can store enough charge to cause injuries, so they must be discharged properly.

This guide will show you how to make a simple resistor-based capacitor discharge tool.

## 1. Step 1
- To construct a capacitor discharge tool, first gather the necessary materials. These include:
  - Two lengths of wire. Minimum wire requirements is 12AWG, 600 volt rating for large electrolytic  capacitors used in power supplies, electric motor start circuits and camera flash circuitry
  - A resistor rated to dissipate the amount of thermal energy created when discharging the capacitor. Minimum requirements for resistor is 2k OHM 5w for small capacitors, 20k OHM 5w for large electrolytic capacitors used in power supplies, electric motor start circuits and camera flash circuitry.
  - Shrink tubing
![Step 1 Image 36259](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OWFqMgtGJtlahiev.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OWFqMgtGJtlahiev.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OWFqMgtGJtlahiev.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OWFqMgtGJtlahiev.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/OWFqMgtGJtlahiev.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Begin the process by stripping one side end of each length of wire.
> **Note:** To ensure a solid solder joint, strip at least .25" of insulation off the wire.
![Step 2 Image 36260](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/yVv1ZuX4gGPCxaCQ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/yVv1ZuX4gGPCxaCQ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/yVv1ZuX4gGPCxaCQ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/yVv1ZuX4gGPCxaCQ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/yVv1ZuX4gGPCxaCQ.full -->
![Step 2 Image 36261](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UPDhAuQSFqZoBXSQ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UPDhAuQSFqZoBXSQ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UPDhAuQSFqZoBXSQ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UPDhAuQSFqZoBXSQ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UPDhAuQSFqZoBXSQ.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- Next, trim both of the leads leaving the resistor to match the length of insulation stripped off the wires in the previous step.
![Step 3 Image 36262](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3D6PJNgTAtEFNWnQ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3D6PJNgTAtEFNWnQ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3D6PJNgTAtEFNWnQ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3D6PJNgTAtEFNWnQ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3D6PJNgTAtEFNWnQ.full -->
![Step 3 Image 36263](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/uwbwg1KGoxTP5Dxp.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/uwbwg1KGoxTP5Dxp.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/uwbwg1KGoxTP5Dxp.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/uwbwg1KGoxTP5Dxp.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/uwbwg1KGoxTP5Dxp.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- Join the lead leaving the resistor to the stripped end of the wire by twisting the two together.
> **Note:** The wire we are using is quite thick, so we inserted the resistor lead down the center of the conductor portion of the wire and twisted the wire against it as tightly as possible.
- Solder the wire to the resistor.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** It is essential that enough solder flows through the wire to create a permanent bond between the two pieces.
![Step 4 Image 36264](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5cgXgYKRqhLZLlbA.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5cgXgYKRqhLZLlbA.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5cgXgYKRqhLZLlbA.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5cgXgYKRqhLZLlbA.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5cgXgYKRqhLZLlbA.full -->
![Step 4 Image 36265](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/H6rGWNaDwII42sPT.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/H6rGWNaDwII42sPT.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/H6rGWNaDwII42sPT.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/H6rGWNaDwII42sPT.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/H6rGWNaDwII42sPT.full -->
![Step 4 Image 36266](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/u5L3IlDPKjQD4X4Y.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/u5L3IlDPKjQD4X4Y.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/u5L3IlDPKjQD4X4Y.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/u5L3IlDPKjQD4X4Y.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/u5L3IlDPKjQD4X4Y.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- Slide a section of shrink tubing up the wire, making sure to completely cover up the solder joint and any exposed wire.
- Use a heat gun or lighter to shrink the tubing over the joint, making sure it is positioned to cover all exposed wire.
![Step 5 Image 36267](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3wXktcjlRfrJmpLW.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3wXktcjlRfrJmpLW.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3wXktcjlRfrJmpLW.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3wXktcjlRfrJmpLW.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3wXktcjlRfrJmpLW.full -->
![Step 5 Image 36268](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oFXMQBUUARWQBJhd.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oFXMQBUUARWQBJhd.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oFXMQBUUARWQBJhd.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oFXMQBUUARWQBJhd.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oFXMQBUUARWQBJhd.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- Repeat the above process for the other side of the resistor.
- To complete the discharge tool, strip the ends of the wires.
> **Note:** To discharge from small points, it may be helpful to cut the exposed ends of wire into a point shape and solder them to maintain the shape. Alternatively, the probes commonly used on multimeters can be soldered to the wires to create a more precise discharge tool.
> **Note:** For large electrolytic capacitors used in power supplies, electric motor start circuits, and camera flash units, you may want to solder one end to a large alligator clip and the other to a well insulated screwdriver.
![Step 6 Image 36269](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/b62RVZWXlVbuXpKk.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/b62RVZWXlVbuXpKk.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/b62RVZWXlVbuXpKk.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/b62RVZWXlVbuXpKk.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/b62RVZWXlVbuXpKk.full -->

guides.title: Desoldering Technique
guides.raw_content:
# Desoldering Technique

This guide will show the process of removing solder from a solder junction.

## 1. Step 1
- Gather your solder gun and soldering paste. The soldering paste I use is very cheap and last very long and I apply it with a plastic pry tool, there are other better methods to apply such as the type that comes in a syringe style tube.You will also need desoldering wire or (wick) which conducts heat well and therefore absorbs the old solder.
![Step 1 Image 307564](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IbfNMViAVaPnMuCs.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IbfNMViAVaPnMuCs.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IbfNMViAVaPnMuCs.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IbfNMViAVaPnMuCs.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IbfNMViAVaPnMuCs.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- It is very helpful to add some soldering paste to the area of the logic board you will be removing solder from—it will help make the process easier and prevent from possibly pulling a pad off the logic board. I am desoldering the + and - battery connections above the SPK points in the picture.
- Apply the de-soldering wick to the area you are removing the solder from and hold the solder gun on it so it can soak the solder up in the wick. Be very careful to not leave the solder gun on too long as the logic board components are very fragile.
- Carefully remove the soldering iron and the wick at the same time. If you remove the solder gun first and then the wick the solder can harden and you could possibly pull components off the board. As you can see the solder pads on the logic board are clean with no excess and ready for fresh solder.
![Step 2 Image 307573](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6lIrDPo1ZINHicag.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6lIrDPo1ZINHicag.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6lIrDPo1ZINHicag.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6lIrDPo1ZINHicag.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6lIrDPo1ZINHicag.full -->
![Step 2 Image 307570](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TFLpKAnAg2eN1Stj.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TFLpKAnAg2eN1Stj.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TFLpKAnAg2eN1Stj.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TFLpKAnAg2eN1Stj.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TFLpKAnAg2eN1Stj.full -->
![Step 2 Image 307576](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WQRjtGTNXRLTTvtB.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WQRjtGTNXRLTTvtB.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WQRjtGTNXRLTTvtB.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WQRjtGTNXRLTTvtB.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WQRjtGTNXRLTTvtB.full -->

guides.title: Nerf War Instructions
guides.raw_content:
# Nerf War Instructions

Sometimes, office disputes can only be settled with ballistic foam. There is nothing more embarrassing than starting a battle that you can't win, so use this guide to get you on the right track to Nerf-victory.

## 1. Step 1
- Prepare the weapons with any modifications you'd like.
![Step 1 Image 126704](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BCIdLMP4PI5xSBYd.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BCIdLMP4PI5xSBYd.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BCIdLMP4PI5xSBYd.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BCIdLMP4PI5xSBYd.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BCIdLMP4PI5xSBYd.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Practice the laser before outright war.
![Step 2 Image 126703](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6rL2HUtOaOskDXMZ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6rL2HUtOaOskDXMZ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6rL2HUtOaOskDXMZ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6rL2HUtOaOskDXMZ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6rL2HUtOaOskDXMZ.full -->

guides.title: Repairing iPhone Liquid Damage
guides.raw_content:
# Repairing iPhone Liquid Damage

Refer to the iPhone [[Topic:iPhone|repair guides]] for instructions on disassembling your iPhone. You may need a soft brush, isopropyl alcohol, and a container that is large enough to submerge your iPhones' logic board in alcohol. The cleaning steps may require several repetitions to achieve a good result. These cleaning suggestions may not restore your phone to working order, but once you have eliminated any liquid and cleaned away any corrosion or debris you may be able to determine if any parts need to be replaced.

For more information consult the [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/liquid/95280|iPhone Liquid Damage Repair|new_window=true] guide.

## 1. Assessing visible external damage
- Look for liquid or residue between the touchscreen and LCD. This phone shows water build-up between the touchscreen and LCD, and most likely contains more liquid inside.
- In this case, there is no obvious damage or corrosion in the external dock connector.
- There is no obvious damage or corrosion in the headphone jack.
![Step 1 Image 107988](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MjAWVcjjEXgaRoSU.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MjAWVcjjEXgaRoSU.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MjAWVcjjEXgaRoSU.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MjAWVcjjEXgaRoSU.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MjAWVcjjEXgaRoSU.full -->
![Step 1 Image 107990](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQHKdnOAwilRmMgk.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQHKdnOAwilRmMgk.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQHKdnOAwilRmMgk.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQHKdnOAwilRmMgk.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQHKdnOAwilRmMgk.full -->
![Step 1 Image 107992](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jsYuTj45U2Sus1GY.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jsYuTj45U2Sus1GY.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jsYuTj45U2Sus1GY.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jsYuTj45U2Sus1GY.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jsYuTj45U2Sus1GY.full -->

## 2. Disassembly
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Liquid damage inside the phone may complicate disassembly. Beware of cables and connectors that may be adhered to other components in unexpected ways.
- Lifting the front panel of this phone, the flex for the dock connector has stuck to the back of the midframe.
![Step 2 Image 107994](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eE1MUQsO16RRkN4G.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eE1MUQsO16RRkN4G.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eE1MUQsO16RRkN4G.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eE1MUQsO16RRkN4G.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eE1MUQsO16RRkN4G.full -->

## 3. Assessing visible internal damage
- The water damage sticker is now pink, indicating that the inside of this phone was flooded with liquid.
- Residue and corrosion discoloration can clearly be seen on the connectors for the LCD, Digitizer, and proximity sensor, as well as the camera and SIM card slot.
![Step 3 Image 111051](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/sYEwEllkxHarue1E.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/sYEwEllkxHarue1E.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/sYEwEllkxHarue1E.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/sYEwEllkxHarue1E.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/sYEwEllkxHarue1E.full -->
![Step 3 Image 111053](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iYId2fIuMEvnGq3q.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iYId2fIuMEvnGq3q.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iYId2fIuMEvnGq3q.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iYId2fIuMEvnGq3q.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/iYId2fIuMEvnGq3q.full -->
![Step 3 Image 111052](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WwIxVuon4Vqif5HL.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WwIxVuon4Vqif5HL.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WwIxVuon4Vqif5HL.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WwIxVuon4Vqif5HL.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WwIxVuon4Vqif5HL.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- The dock connector water sensor sticker has turned pink too, indicating liquid flooding of this end of the phone.
- The top of this dock connector looks fairly clean, with only a few green corrosive changes near connector 4.
![Step 4 Image 111055](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QbLgJ6qSiQdrvOSe.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QbLgJ6qSiQdrvOSe.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QbLgJ6qSiQdrvOSe.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QbLgJ6qSiQdrvOSe.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QbLgJ6qSiQdrvOSe.full -->
![Step 4 Image 111054](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/T4oxNS5LMeKTNEaU.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/T4oxNS5LMeKTNEaU.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/T4oxNS5LMeKTNEaU.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/T4oxNS5LMeKTNEaU.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/T4oxNS5LMeKTNEaU.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- The rear of the display assembly shows more green corrosion and debris on the LCD and digitizer connectors.
- Removing the LCD and the back cover of the ear speaker and proximity sensor assembly reveals liquid damage to the speaker.
- The proximity sensor is only lightly damaged.
![Step 5 Image 111056](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1djlvFeT1b2WROfA.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1djlvFeT1b2WROfA.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1djlvFeT1b2WROfA.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1djlvFeT1b2WROfA.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1djlvFeT1b2WROfA.full -->
![Step 5 Image 111057](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JCLPNDPPFPYCLbfB.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JCLPNDPPFPYCLbfB.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JCLPNDPPFPYCLbfB.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JCLPNDPPFPYCLbfB.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JCLPNDPPFPYCLbfB.full -->
![Step 5 Image 111060](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UB2XVmRGM6OjetDx.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UB2XVmRGM6OjetDx.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UB2XVmRGM6OjetDx.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UB2XVmRGM6OjetDx.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UB2XVmRGM6OjetDx.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- Closer inspection of proximity sensor/earpiece flex reveals more corrosion damage.
![Step 6 Image 108020](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/baeYtkfRDHA2Qvqt.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/baeYtkfRDHA2Qvqt.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/baeYtkfRDHA2Qvqt.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/baeYtkfRDHA2Qvqt.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/baeYtkfRDHA2Qvqt.full -->

## 7. Step 7
- After removing the logic board, more liquid damage is visible.
- The vibration motor has some rust.
- The battery pins have corroded.
![Step 7 Image 111065](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wUpOvItDAZpRDrLr.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wUpOvItDAZpRDrLr.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wUpOvItDAZpRDrLr.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wUpOvItDAZpRDrLr.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/wUpOvItDAZpRDrLr.full -->

## 8. Step 8
- Headphone jack connector 5, the vibration motor, and the volume switch show some light corrosion.
![Step 8 Image 108058](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/f1ypUPbpxMtYJlIP.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/f1ypUPbpxMtYJlIP.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/f1ypUPbpxMtYJlIP.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/f1ypUPbpxMtYJlIP.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/f1ypUPbpxMtYJlIP.full -->

## 9. Step 9
- Rear of motherboard showing some signs of corrosion to battery contacts.
![Step 9 Image 108060](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gthLRfAVRvaqYPgv.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gthLRfAVRvaqYPgv.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gthLRfAVRvaqYPgv.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gthLRfAVRvaqYPgv.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gthLRfAVRvaqYPgv.full -->
![Step 9 Image 108059](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4YJYWO5RXOHA4K5i.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4YJYWO5RXOHA4K5i.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4YJYWO5RXOHA4K5i.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4YJYWO5RXOHA4K5i.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4YJYWO5RXOHA4K5i.full -->

## 10. Removing the logic board shield cover
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Depending on the nature of the liquid damage, removing this shield may not be necessary, and doing so risks damaging the small components mounted on the logic board. If you decide to remove the shield, proceed cautiously and use a plastic tool such as a [product|IF145-002|spudger], or a [product|IF145-000|plastic opening tool] to lever off the shield.
- Look for the dimpled tabs on the shield that reach down over the tabs attached to the mother board.
- Using your plastic tool, catch the edge of a dimpled tab near a corner of the shield, and pry it up away from the logic board.
- Being careful of all the tiny surface mounted components, work your way around the available edges until the shield comes free.
![Step 10 Image 111097](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1ELRjo4fZZMQWtwg.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1ELRjo4fZZMQWtwg.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1ELRjo4fZZMQWtwg.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1ELRjo4fZZMQWtwg.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1ELRjo4fZZMQWtwg.full -->
![Step 10 Image 108062](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bc3ryPBKKifkTVPO.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bc3ryPBKKifkTVPO.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bc3ryPBKKifkTVPO.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bc3ryPBKKifkTVPO.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bc3ryPBKKifkTVPO.full -->

## 11. Cleaning the logic board
- Submerge the logic board in isopropyl alcohol, and allow it to soak long enough to loosen hardened residue, and to displace any remaining water or other liquid. Use a soft brush to remove visible corrosion and residue.
- Residue from motherboard left in isopropyl alcohol container.
- Clean all flex ends, battery contacts, connectors, chips, and fuses on motherboard with a soft brush.
- Repeat cleaning if necessary, or if traces of residue are still visible.
- Allow the logic board or other parts to dry completely before reassembly.
![Step 11 Image 108088](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TYTijXyLXn3JvliU.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TYTijXyLXn3JvliU.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TYTijXyLXn3JvliU.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TYTijXyLXn3JvliU.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TYTijXyLXn3JvliU.full -->
![Step 11 Image 111085](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/aIJkpOsUH4CdkjeP.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/aIJkpOsUH4CdkjeP.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/aIJkpOsUH4CdkjeP.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/aIJkpOsUH4CdkjeP.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/aIJkpOsUH4CdkjeP.full -->

## 12. Cleaning the LCD
- Wipe LCD with cloth moistened with isopropyl alcohol. Immersion isn't advised, as liquid may leave a mark behind the LCD.
- This is the screen after cleaning. Water mark is no longer visible.
![Step 12 Image 108094](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SkO6LY5awojVfOpW.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SkO6LY5awojVfOpW.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SkO6LY5awojVfOpW.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SkO6LY5awojVfOpW.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/SkO6LY5awojVfOpW.full -->

## Conclusion

To reassemble your device refer to the iPhone [[Topic:iPhone|repair guides]] for your particular phone.

After repeated cleaning, this example phone needed connectors 1, 2, and 3 replaced on the logic board, a new LCD, and digitizer. Corrosion on the cable ends and connectors could not be adequately removed. All other functions worked and this iPhone is now back in working order. Good luck. Hopefully this guide demonstrates that liquid damage to your iPhone isn't always obvious or visible and that disassembly and cleaning may benefit some phones exposed to liquid.

guides.title: (OBSOLETE) How to jailbreak iOS 4.0 - 4.0.1
guides.raw_content:
# (OBSOLETE) How to jailbreak iOS 4.0 - 4.0.1

'''IMPORTANT: THIS GUIDE IS OBSOLETE. Very few modern apps support iOS 4.x and methods like this have been superseded.'''

Jailbreaking your iOS device installs Cydia, an alternative to the App Store, which is full of cool things like themes, tweaks, and apps that you won't find on the App Store, like Grooveshark (Apple blocked it) and Mewseek, which allows you to add music to your iOS Device without syncing it with iTunes.

This guide will show you how to use jailbreakme.com, designed by @comex, to jailbreak iOS firmwares 4.0 and 4.0.1 .

WARNING: Jailbreaking technically voids your Apple warranty, however, you can easily get your warranty back by restoring your iOS Device to stock Apple firmware using iTunes.

## 1. Step 1
- First step, power on your iDevice if you haven't already done so.
- Now, once you're powered up and ready, navigate to settings.app and turn on WiFi and connect to a network.
![Step 1 Image 133973](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UBStXEHm5GWyN4RJ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UBStXEHm5GWyN4RJ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UBStXEHm5GWyN4RJ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UBStXEHm5GWyN4RJ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UBStXEHm5GWyN4RJ.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Now, close settings and open up Safari.app
- Navigate your browser to http://www.jailbreakme.com
- slide to jailbreak!
![Step 2 Image 133968](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQnVSsgEeDAE5EfL.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQnVSsgEeDAE5EfL.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQnVSsgEeDAE5EfL.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQnVSsgEeDAE5EfL.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mQnVSsgEeDAE5EfL.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- There is now a short interlude whilst safari downloads a pdf, which is how jailbreak me.com works.
- Then it'll do some stuff which actually jailbreaks the device and install Cydia for you.
- Then it'll tell you it's done and Cydia is installed on the home screen, then it will reboot, this might take a little longer than you're used to.
![Step 3 Image 125832](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AB3mpGCIH6fvgSKQ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AB3mpGCIH6fvgSKQ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AB3mpGCIH6fvgSKQ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AB3mpGCIH6fvgSKQ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AB3mpGCIH6fvgSKQ.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- When you've successfully rebooted, Cydia will be on one your pages of apps, usually not the first page.
- Launch Cydia and it will reorganise some files and then respring your iPod, which is like logging out and then back in to your PC almost.
- Launch Cydia again and it'll ask whether you're a User, a Developer or a Hacker. Most people are users, leave the scary stuff alone, you probably won't need it.
- Cydia will now refresh it's sources and reload its data, once that's done, you can browse it's vast collection of tweaks, apps and themes.
- You're done! If you have any problems, check out jailbreakqa.com which is full of helpful people who know all about jailbreaking.
- Credit to @comex for the exploit, untether and jailbreakme.com and huge credit to @Saurik for writing, developing and maintaining Cydia.
![Step 4 Image 133971](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5YIRikYieBSRAigM.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5YIRikYieBSRAigM.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5YIRikYieBSRAigM.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5YIRikYieBSRAigM.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5YIRikYieBSRAigM.full -->

guides.title: Electronics Skills Kit 101
guides.raw_content:
# Electronics Skills Kit 101

So you just purchased our Level 1 Soldering Kit to practice your through-hole soldering. This guide will help you through the steps while teaching you about soldering, resistor reading, and component polarity. Soon, you'll be ready to replace the battery in your  [guide|749|iPod Nano 3rd Generation|stepid=4006].

## 1. Step 1
- Before diving into the assembly of your brain game, we should go over the procedure for through-hole soldering.
- Why is it called through-hole, you ask? You'll notice the circuit board has a bunch of holes in it, each with a copper trace on the underside of the board. The leads of each component are fed through these holes (hence through-hole) and soldered to the copper trace.
> **Note:** Through-hole soldering is generally regarded as the simplest form of soldering.
![Step 1 Image 121456](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/It1W4dOcuXtABas5.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/It1W4dOcuXtABas5.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/It1W4dOcuXtABas5.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/It1W4dOcuXtABas5.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/It1W4dOcuXtABas5.full -->
![Step 1 Image 121177](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGJMXqrKn1GVcvC6.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGJMXqrKn1GVcvC6.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGJMXqrKn1GVcvC6.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGJMXqrKn1GVcvC6.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JGJMXqrKn1GVcvC6.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- The most important tool for any soldering job? Your soldering iron, of course! For this procedure we'll be using the soldering station that we sell in our parts and tools store.
- For this project, you won't want your soldering iron to exceed 40 watts ''at the tip''. For our station which ''draws'' 50 watts of power from the wall, it is safe to crank it up all the way to max.
- If this is the first time you're firing up your soldering iron, you may notice some smoke and a not-so-pleasant scent. Don't worry; this is just the coating on the tip burning off. Wait a couple minutes for the soldering iron to stop smoking.
- Before you start soldering, be sure to dampen your cleaning sponge. A dry sponge will just get burned.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** It is always a good precaution to wear safety goggles while soldering. Hot pieces of solder occasionally shoot off and a scorching piece of metal to the eye will ruin even the greatest optimist's day.
![Step 2 Image 121176](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pIeELUYshAoWxHpD.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pIeELUYshAoWxHpD.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pIeELUYshAoWxHpD.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pIeELUYshAoWxHpD.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pIeELUYshAoWxHpD.full -->
![Step 2 Image 121178](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AFCDHNWVF2gqXIMS.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AFCDHNWVF2gqXIMS.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AFCDHNWVF2gqXIMS.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AFCDHNWVF2gqXIMS.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AFCDHNWVF2gqXIMS.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- We'll start with resistor R1 in your kit, which has yellow, purple, brown, and gold rings on it (more on what these colored rings mean later).
- Bend the leads of the resistor to 90^^o^^ angles about 1.5 mm away from the body of the resistor.
![Step 3 Image 121174](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oXtBCtCIfgVbYOTm.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oXtBCtCIfgVbYOTm.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oXtBCtCIfgVbYOTm.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oXtBCtCIfgVbYOTm.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oXtBCtCIfgVbYOTm.full -->
![Step 3 Image 121175](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EROONucHdvCegqyk.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EROONucHdvCegqyk.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EROONucHdvCegqyk.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EROONucHdvCegqyk.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EROONucHdvCegqyk.full -->
![Step 3 Image 121179](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CZoLbrQKvIntSllN.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CZoLbrQKvIntSllN.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CZoLbrQKvIntSllN.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CZoLbrQKvIntSllN.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CZoLbrQKvIntSllN.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- Place the leads of the resistor through the holes on either side of the rectangle marked '''R1''' on the circuit board.
> **Note:** Resistors do not have to be installed in a particular orientation. Either lead can go into either hole.
- Turn the board over so that the copper traces are facing up and the resistor leads are pointing straight up in the air, as seen in the second picture.
> **Note:** You may also bend the leads outward to hold the resistor in place, but this is not necessary. As per NASA guidelines, any angle up to 30° down from vertical is acceptable.
![Step 4 Image 121180](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pDlFquAATTFBuRPF.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pDlFquAATTFBuRPF.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pDlFquAATTFBuRPF.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pDlFquAATTFBuRPF.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/pDlFquAATTFBuRPF.full -->
![Step 4 Image 121181](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mVZ2usDSEuddQyZc.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mVZ2usDSEuddQyZc.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mVZ2usDSEuddQyZc.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mVZ2usDSEuddQyZc.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mVZ2usDSEuddQyZc.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- You must be itching to throw down some molten metal by now; however, you still need to prepare the tip of your soldering iron.
- Now that your soldering iron's tip is hot, clean it by melting a small amount of solder directly on the tip and wiping it off on your damp sponge.
- Melt another small ball of solder onto the tip of the soldering iron, but do not wipe it off. This is called "tinning" the iron, and will improve heat conductivity, allowing you to solder more quickly and efficiently.
> **Note:** Regular cleaning and tinning of your soldering iron while working will lead to better solder joints and longer tip life.
![Step 5 Image 121453](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HKEEAeOXxNj4qhPd.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HKEEAeOXxNj4qhPd.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HKEEAeOXxNj4qhPd.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HKEEAeOXxNj4qhPd.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HKEEAeOXxNj4qhPd.full -->
![Step 5 Image 121183](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/antYqvNHf316M36g.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/antYqvNHf316M36g.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/antYqvNHf316M36g.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/antYqvNHf316M36g.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/antYqvNHf316M36g.full -->
![Step 5 Image 121184](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IIpIPV5wXKvqIvjI.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IIpIPV5wXKvqIvjI.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IIpIPV5wXKvqIvjI.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IIpIPV5wXKvqIvjI.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IIpIPV5wXKvqIvjI.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- Here we are: the moment of truth. It's time to get that solder flowing.
- Set the tip of the [product|IF145-495|soldering iron|new_window=true] on the two parts to be connected. In this case, that's the resistor lead and the copper trace on the circuit board.
- Touch your solder to the tip of your soldering iron to melt it onto the joint. Don't hold it there for more than a second or two.
- Quickly, but not frantically, pull both the soldering iron and the solder away from the joint.
- Your solder joint should be shiny and conical, and not expand beyond the copper trace.
![Step 6 Image 121185](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jpPixVGrbR2srAHy.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jpPixVGrbR2srAHy.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jpPixVGrbR2srAHy.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jpPixVGrbR2srAHy.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/jpPixVGrbR2srAHy.full -->
![Step 6 Image 121186](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Zh2SNRIPwJ5RqRdC.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Zh2SNRIPwJ5RqRdC.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Zh2SNRIPwJ5RqRdC.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Zh2SNRIPwJ5RqRdC.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Zh2SNRIPwJ5RqRdC.full -->
![Step 6 Image 121187](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AuHDI5SBdnsBEDNA.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AuHDI5SBdnsBEDNA.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AuHDI5SBdnsBEDNA.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AuHDI5SBdnsBEDNA.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/AuHDI5SBdnsBEDNA.full -->

## 7. Step 7
- Use the same method above to solder the second resistor lead to the circuit board.
> **Note:** After soldering a joint, if you are going to put the soldering iron down, be sure to place it back in its stand to prevent burning yourself or anything around you.
- Cut the extra lengths of the resistor leads with a pair of wire cutters. NASA workmanship standards state that any length up to 2.29 mm is acceptable.
![Step 7 Image 121188](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vCjYRpK4nBDgRoeL.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vCjYRpK4nBDgRoeL.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vCjYRpK4nBDgRoeL.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vCjYRpK4nBDgRoeL.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vCjYRpK4nBDgRoeL.full -->
![Step 7 Image 121317](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3xQheAJh6uBZadpU.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3xQheAJh6uBZadpU.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3xQheAJh6uBZadpU.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3xQheAJh6uBZadpU.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3xQheAJh6uBZadpU.full -->
![Step 7 Image 121316](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/nVNVyUjK2qAl6oIR.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/nVNVyUjK2qAl6oIR.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/nVNVyUjK2qAl6oIR.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/nVNVyUjK2qAl6oIR.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/nVNVyUjK2qAl6oIR.full -->

## 8. Step 8
- We all make mistakes, especially when trying something new. Soldering is no exception, so here's what to do when one of your soldered joints comes out less than ideal.
- Lay a strand of desoldering braid over the solder in question. Press the tip of the soldering iron firmly onto the desoldering braid. This will heat up both the solder and the braid.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** Do not hold the braid close to the solder point while using it—it gets very hot and can burn you.
> **Note:** Be careful not to lay the desoldering braid across the fiberglass circuit board. As the braid heats up, it could leave marks in the board.
- The solder should flow from the joint to the desoldering braid. After the solder flows into the braid, remove it and the soldering iron from the board. You should now have a clean contact to start over with. Use wire cutters to cut off the used end of the desoldering braid.
![Step 8 Image 121236](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/cth6eU2C3XwJ6VG6.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/cth6eU2C3XwJ6VG6.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/cth6eU2C3XwJ6VG6.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/cth6eU2C3XwJ6VG6.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/cth6eU2C3XwJ6VG6.full -->
![Step 8 Image 121237](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gnAajFmvNRtrJo2b.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gnAajFmvNRtrJo2b.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gnAajFmvNRtrJo2b.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gnAajFmvNRtrJo2b.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/gnAajFmvNRtrJo2b.full -->

## 9. Step 9
- So, what are resistors, and why do we care about them? Resistors are components used in circuitry to control the amount of current flow. The more resistance a resistor has (measured in Ohms, Ω), the less current it allows to flow.
- The colored bands on a resistor are the key to determining the resistance of that particular resistor. A [http://www.bcdxc.org/resistor_color_codes.htm|resistor color code chart] will come in handy here.
- If there are four bands on your resistor, the first band to locate is the red, gold, or silver band on one of the swollen ends; these are called tolerance bands. Since our resistors have gold bands, we know the actual resistance is within ±5% of the nominal value
- The next step is to determine the nominal value of your resistor. Starting at the opposite side of the tolerance band and moving from left to right, there are three colored bands. The first two color bands correspond to a number (0-9), and the third band is the multiplier band, which corresponds to a specific power of 10.
- Looking at the top resistor shown, we see yellow, violet, and red bands. Consulting a resistor color code chart shows us that those correspond to 4, 7, and 100, respectively, giving us a nominal resistance of 4,700 Ω.
> **Note:** Can you determine the resistance of the bottom resistor?
![Step 9 Image 121323](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VZ5UnKe3jMmnegEV.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VZ5UnKe3jMmnegEV.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VZ5UnKe3jMmnegEV.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VZ5UnKe3jMmnegEV.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VZ5UnKe3jMmnegEV.full -->

## 10. Step 10
- Install the three remaining 470 Ω resistors (yellow/violet/brown) into the terminals marked '''R2''', '''R3''', and '''R4'''.
![Step 10 Image 121318](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Sv5iK2eHcVRqJjRM.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Sv5iK2eHcVRqJjRM.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Sv5iK2eHcVRqJjRM.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Sv5iK2eHcVRqJjRM.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Sv5iK2eHcVRqJjRM.full -->
![Step 10 Image 121193](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GEAOOAChvydFtcWM.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GEAOOAChvydFtcWM.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GEAOOAChvydFtcWM.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GEAOOAChvydFtcWM.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GEAOOAChvydFtcWM.full -->
![Step 10 Image 121194](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/E2MOvVNmnyrcNZMq.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/E2MOvVNmnyrcNZMq.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/E2MOvVNmnyrcNZMq.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/E2MOvVNmnyrcNZMq.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/E2MOvVNmnyrcNZMq.full -->

## 11. Step 11
- Fish the two yellow/violet/red resistors out of your kit.
> **Note:** Consulting our resistor color code chart tells us that these resistors have a 4,700 Ω resistance.
- Install these two resistors into the '''R5''' and '''R6''' terminals on the circuit board.
![Step 11 Image 121195](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YmSMSgEkWPyCDRFw.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YmSMSgEkWPyCDRFw.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YmSMSgEkWPyCDRFw.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YmSMSgEkWPyCDRFw.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/YmSMSgEkWPyCDRFw.full -->
![Step 11 Image 121322](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tTgaBsfjXO56K2fO.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tTgaBsfjXO56K2fO.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tTgaBsfjXO56K2fO.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tTgaBsfjXO56K2fO.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tTgaBsfjXO56K2fO.full -->
![Step 11 Image 121320](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/o4kkNYniSVhvpbBd.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/o4kkNYniSVhvpbBd.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/o4kkNYniSVhvpbBd.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/o4kkNYniSVhvpbBd.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/o4kkNYniSVhvpbBd.full -->

## 12. Step 12
- Locate your single yellow/violet/black resistor.
> **Note:** Try figuring out the nominal resistance value yourself before we tell you that it's 47 Ω.
- Install this resistor into the terminal marked '''R7''' on the circuit board.
![Step 12 Image 121199](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IRyITNO5ONdH2POn.full)

## 13. Step 13
- Dig around your kit a little more, and you'll find some new and exciting components with long leads attached to them.
- These are diodes—circuitry's "one way" signs. Their job is to make sure that current only travels in the forward direction, from anode to cathode, while blocking it from traveling in reverse. Current enters the anode (positive terminal) and leaves the cathode (negative terminal).
- Since they only allow current to travel in one direction, it is rather pertinent that you install diodes with the correct polarity. The stripe on a diode signifies which side is the cathode.
![Step 13 Image 121202](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BNfHDC2le4OQDHJd.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BNfHDC2le4OQDHJd.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BNfHDC2le4OQDHJd.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BNfHDC2le4OQDHJd.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/BNfHDC2le4OQDHJd.full -->

## 14. Step 14
- Bend the leads of the small red diode and insert them into the terminal marked '''D1'''.
> **Note:** Make sure that the cathode (marked by a small black band) lines up with the white stripe to the left of where it says '''D1''' on the circuit board.
- Use the same method you used to solder the resistors to the board to install the diode.
![Step 14 Image 121330](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Eh4Bdvbrlwg2M55l.full)

## 15. Step 15
- Install the larger, black diode into the terminal marked '''D2'''.
> **Note:** Don't forget to line up the gray end of the diode with the side of the terminal marked for the cathode.
![Step 15 Image 121331](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vtI5myPSLWTHWTRS.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vtI5myPSLWTHWTRS.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vtI5myPSLWTHWTRS.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vtI5myPSLWTHWTRS.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vtI5myPSLWTHWTRS.full -->

## 16. Step 16
- No game is really a game until there are buttons involved, so let's put those on the board next.
- Insert the leads of the four buttons into the spots marked '''SW1''' through '''SW4'''.
- There is no particular orientation that the buttons must be installed in, as long as the leads are properly seated in their holes.

## 17. Step 17
- Solder each of the leads for each button.
- The technique for soldering the buttons is the exact same as soldering the resistors and diodes, except that you do not need to cut any excess leads after soldering the joint.
![Step 17 Image 121211](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/KkALLfpllChJsmJJ.full)

## 18. Step 18
- Next you will install the IC socket, also known as a CPU socket. IC sockets use a mechanical connection to connect a processor to a printed circuit board. These sockets allows the processor to be easily replaced without the risk of damage associated with soldering processors directly to a circuit board.
- Stick the eight leads of the IC socket through the holes in the rectangle marked IC1. Make sure that the semi-circle on the top of the socket lines up with the semi-circle printed on the edge of the rectangle on the circuit board.
- Turn the board over and solder the eight leads of the IC socket to the board. Similar to soldering the buttons, there is no need to trim any excess off the leads.
![Step 18 Image 121213](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HiwCyqQVnVcsaYLS.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HiwCyqQVnVcsaYLS.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HiwCyqQVnVcsaYLS.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HiwCyqQVnVcsaYLS.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HiwCyqQVnVcsaYLS.full -->

## 19. Step 19
- The next component we will be installing is the yellow capacitor. Capacitors store electrical charge, and are helpful when a circuit needs a quick shot of energy to illuminate a light or make a beep.
- Capacitors are measured (in Farads) as the ratio of the electrical charge on each conductor to the potential difference between them. This capacitor is a 1 µF capacitor.
- Install the capacitor in the terminal next to the IC socket marked '''C1'''. Soldering the leads of a capacitor follows the same through-hole procedure used thus far.
> **Note:** Make sure that the printed markings on the capacitor face away from the IC socket so that you can still read it.
![Step 19 Image 121215](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CjvXdYYVaPNwlWb1.full)

## 20. Step 20
- The next components to install are the LEDs. Light emitting diodes are used in all sorts of electronics to provide bright, different colored lights.
> **Note:** Note that the two leads are different lengths. Since an LED is a diode, it only allows current to travel in one direction, so it is important to install the correct lead in the correct hole.
- The four LEDs belong in each of the four terminals marked '''LD1''' through '''LD4'''.
- When installing the LEDs, insert the shorter of the two leads into the hole next to the flat part of the printed circle.
![Step 20 Image 121218](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kLFBTxcNlZeMmDJr.full)

## 21. Step 21
- Solder each of the LEDs to the circuit board and cut the excess off each lead.

## 22. Step 22
- Another cool electrical component‽ How exciting!
- Transistors are used to amplify and/or switch electrical signals. This means that they can either increase an input voltage, or be used as electronic on-off switches.
- The important thing to pay attention to when installing a transistor is that you solder each lead to the correct spot, because each one has a different purpose.
  - One is used as the current source.
  - One is used as a gate.
  - One is used as a current output.
![Step 22 Image 121226](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oEAkEcUc5PkAG1Lp.full)

## 23. Step 23
- Locate the semi-circle labeled '''T1''' and insert the three leads through the holes.
> **Note:** Make sure that you line up the flat part of the transistor with the flat edge of the semi-circle on the board. The two end leads fit into the holes on the ends of the flat part of the drawing. The middle lead will need to be bent so that it feeds through the hole closest to the '''T1'''.
- Solder the three leads to the board and cut the excess off the leads.

> **Note:** Note the '''+''' on the face of the speaker. When installing the speaker, be sure to line this '''+''' up with the '''+''' on the circuit board.

## 26. Step 26
- ''' Bonus! ''' You thought you were just learning how to through-hole solder, but Included with this kit is a complimentary intro to [guide|750|surface-mount soldering|stepid=4050]. Surface-mount soldering is commonly used to attach batteries to circuit boards in some devices, such as  [guide|3306|iPods|stepid=16238].
- Set the tip of your soldering iron on the large copper negative solder pad. This will allow heat to conduct through the solder pad, making soldering easier.
- Touch your solder to the tip of the soldering iron and keep feeding it until you have a smooth, convex solder dome on the copper pad.
> **Note:** If the solder doesn't come out quite right, you can always use the iron to melt it again or add more solder.
![Step 26 Image 121240](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IyANEJpQP3IV6Jjk.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IyANEJpQP3IV6Jjk.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IyANEJpQP3IV6Jjk.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IyANEJpQP3IV6Jjk.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IyANEJpQP3IV6Jjk.full -->

<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FrLVVa4UAUvHLIME.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FrLVVa4UAUvHLIME.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FrLVVa4UAUvHLIME.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FrLVVa4UAUvHLIME.full -->
![Step 26 Image 121238](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eY3CFl5lcETUZtYE.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eY3CFl5lcETUZtYE.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eY3CFl5lcETUZtYE.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eY3CFl5lcETUZtYE.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/eY3CFl5lcETUZtYE.full -->

## 27. Step 27
- Repeat this process for the positive solder pad.
- You should end up with two long, smooth, convex domes of solder.
![Step 27 Image 121241](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NQbGpdDwnPLKthKU.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NQbGpdDwnPLKthKU.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NQbGpdDwnPLKthKU.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NQbGpdDwnPLKthKU.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NQbGpdDwnPLKthKU.full -->
![Step 27 Image 121243](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rTSdNLDWXLXmCBvi.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rTSdNLDWXLXmCBvi.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rTSdNLDWXLXmCBvi.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rTSdNLDWXLXmCBvi.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rTSdNLDWXLXmCBvi.full -->

## 28. Step 28
- No, you weren't ripped off; those two leads aren't supposed to have any components in the middle of them.
- To solder the battery leads to the circuit board, set the tip of the soldering iron on the solder that's on the positive pad.
- When the solder begins to melt again, quickly insert the end of the lead into the melted solder so that the lead hangs off the side of the board, as shown.
> ⚠️ **Caution:** The leads will heat up and may burn you if you hold them near the soldering iron for more than a few seconds.
- Remove the soldering iron and let the solder cool around the lead.
> **Note:** You can melt the solder again or add more solder if you don't get it right the first time.
![Step 28 Image 121242](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GQqPDflv6OKvoTbX.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GQqPDflv6OKvoTbX.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GQqPDflv6OKvoTbX.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GQqPDflv6OKvoTbX.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GQqPDflv6OKvoTbX.full -->
![Step 28 Image 121244](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J6LCeVIgHjNxWAct.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J6LCeVIgHjNxWAct.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J6LCeVIgHjNxWAct.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J6LCeVIgHjNxWAct.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/J6LCeVIgHjNxWAct.full -->
![Step 28 Image 121245](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2PiX6PKXJjJWf2ZV.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2PiX6PKXJjJWf2ZV.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2PiX6PKXJjJWf2ZV.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2PiX6PKXJjJWf2ZV.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/2PiX6PKXJjJWf2ZV.full -->

## 29. Step 29
- Repeat the surface mount soldering procedure for the negative battery terminal lead. Be sure to install the lead so that the excess wire hangs off the opposite side rather than the positive terminal lead.
- Now that you have installed whiskers on your circuit board, it's time to pet it and buy it a scratching post. Wait, that's not right . . .
![Step 29 Image 121247](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UsGOwYK5rJbBqYjb.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UsGOwYK5rJbBqYjb.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UsGOwYK5rJbBqYjb.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UsGOwYK5rJbBqYjb.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UsGOwYK5rJbBqYjb.full -->

## 30. Step 30
- Insert the two Phillips screws through the holes in the underside of the battery compartment.
![Step 30 Image 121248](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NCSktXC6PlhEauHG.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NCSktXC6PlhEauHG.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NCSktXC6PlhEauHG.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NCSktXC6PlhEauHG.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/NCSktXC6PlhEauHG.full -->
![Step 30 Image 121249](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1pYOsmZnrQPAmWjH.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1pYOsmZnrQPAmWjH.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1pYOsmZnrQPAmWjH.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1pYOsmZnrQPAmWjH.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1pYOsmZnrQPAmWjH.full -->

## 31. Step 31
- Place two fingers of one hand over the screw heads.
- Keeping your fingers on the screw heads to hold them in place, grab the battery compartment with your thumb and flip it over. The screw threads should protrude out of the top side of the battery compartment.
![Step 31 Image 121250](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vvyBMa2Mi6TdC5Qc.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vvyBMa2Mi6TdC5Qc.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vvyBMa2Mi6TdC5Qc.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vvyBMa2Mi6TdC5Qc.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vvyBMa2Mi6TdC5Qc.full -->
![Step 31 Image 121251](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqDr2QJYIef1VNUO.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqDr2QJYIef1VNUO.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqDr2QJYIef1VNUO.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqDr2QJYIef1VNUO.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EqDr2QJYIef1VNUO.full -->

## 32. Step 32
- Use your free hand to place the two metal spacers over the screw threads (one per screw).
![Step 32 Image 121252](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1cDJn1ShDuLrqMZR.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1cDJn1ShDuLrqMZR.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1cDJn1ShDuLrqMZR.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1cDJn1ShDuLrqMZR.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1cDJn1ShDuLrqMZR.full -->
![Step 32 Image 121253](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5OYspEMhQCh2F1aM.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5OYspEMhQCh2F1aM.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5OYspEMhQCh2F1aM.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5OYspEMhQCh2F1aM.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5OYspEMhQCh2F1aM.full -->

## 33. Step 33
- Continue holding the screws in place and set the circuit board on top of the battery compartment so that the two screws are fed through the holes on either side of the speaker.
> **Note:** Make sure that the top of the circuit board (the part that says '''Brain Game''') lines up with the side of the battery compartment with three metal rings on the outside, as opposed to two.
- Hand tighten the two nuts onto the battery compartment screws.
![Step 33 Image 121254](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UDuYSTQJkr1bYCd6.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UDuYSTQJkr1bYCd6.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UDuYSTQJkr1bYCd6.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UDuYSTQJkr1bYCd6.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/UDuYSTQJkr1bYCd6.full -->
![Step 33 Image 121255](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/k5VBOxMxObgRmaPe.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/k5VBOxMxObgRmaPe.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/k5VBOxMxObgRmaPe.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/k5VBOxMxObgRmaPe.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/k5VBOxMxObgRmaPe.full -->
![Step 33 Image 121257](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5SIkZPEFEAXyHhiJ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5SIkZPEFEAXyHhiJ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5SIkZPEFEAXyHhiJ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5SIkZPEFEAXyHhiJ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5SIkZPEFEAXyHhiJ.full -->

## 34. Step 34
- Place a 5.5 mm nut driver or socket over one of the battery compartment screw nuts.
- Turn the circuit board over.
- Use one hand to hold the socket in place and tighten the battery compartment screw with a Phillips #2 screwdriver.
- Follow the same procedure to tighten the other battery compartment screw.
![Step 34 Image 121256](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bsDVvL2EVEA13ZAf.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bsDVvL2EVEA13ZAf.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bsDVvL2EVEA13ZAf.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bsDVvL2EVEA13ZAf.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/bsDVvL2EVEA13ZAf.full -->
![Step 34 Image 121258](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/41wJ1frkhGrUTbMV.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/41wJ1frkhGrUTbMV.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/41wJ1frkhGrUTbMV.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/41wJ1frkhGrUTbMV.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/41wJ1frkhGrUTbMV.full -->
![Step 34 Image 121260](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CL6o4ug3Poxl2UUr.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CL6o4ug3Poxl2UUr.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CL6o4ug3Poxl2UUr.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CL6o4ug3Poxl2UUr.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/CL6o4ug3Poxl2UUr.full -->

## 35. Step 35
- Use a spudger to pry the metal rings on the battery terminals up so that they perpendicular to the battery terminals.
> **Note:** These rings should be on the same end as the surface mount leads. If they are on opposite ends, the board is on backwards, and you'll need to unscrew the nuts, rotate the circuit board 180°, reinstall the nuts, and tighten the two screws.
![Step 35 Image 121261](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Rd6a6mK5SVfj3oo4.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Rd6a6mK5SVfj3oo4.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Rd6a6mK5SVfj3oo4.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Rd6a6mK5SVfj3oo4.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/Rd6a6mK5SVfj3oo4.full -->
![Step 35 Image 121262](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/urnV5AtpJEh4CsBG.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/urnV5AtpJEh4CsBG.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/urnV5AtpJEh4CsBG.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/urnV5AtpJEh4CsBG.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/urnV5AtpJEh4CsBG.full -->

## 36. Step 36
- Use a pair of wire cutters to remove about an inch of the positive terminal surface mount lead.
- Bend the lead around and through the positive ring terminal on the battery compartment.
- Use your now perfected through-hole soldering skills to solder the lead to the battery terminal.
- Cut off any excess lead.
![Step 36 Image 121263](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lHKjQImUp5TDZKve.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lHKjQImUp5TDZKve.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lHKjQImUp5TDZKve.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lHKjQImUp5TDZKve.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lHKjQImUp5TDZKve.full -->
![Step 36 Image 121264](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MpGa2vdE3yEE2TUm.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MpGa2vdE3yEE2TUm.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MpGa2vdE3yEE2TUm.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MpGa2vdE3yEE2TUm.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MpGa2vdE3yEE2TUm.full -->
![Step 36 Image 121265](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oZATOwHklbvAYCmI.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oZATOwHklbvAYCmI.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oZATOwHklbvAYCmI.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oZATOwHklbvAYCmI.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/oZATOwHklbvAYCmI.full -->

## 37. Step 37
- Repeat the same procedure for the negative battery terminal lead.
> **Note:** Both leads can be any length or shape you would like, but they must not contact each other or any other components.
![Step 37 Image 121266](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GKXjtIHFnOyccgFR.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GKXjtIHFnOyccgFR.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GKXjtIHFnOyccgFR.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GKXjtIHFnOyccgFR.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/GKXjtIHFnOyccgFR.full -->
![Step 37 Image 121267](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QZsWMVT1K5ORlKh4.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QZsWMVT1K5ORlKh4.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QZsWMVT1K5ORlKh4.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QZsWMVT1K5ORlKh4.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/QZsWMVT1K5ORlKh4.full -->
![Step 37 Image 121268](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kDGiRgSBiUJdeTDD.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kDGiRgSBiUJdeTDD.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kDGiRgSBiUJdeTDD.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kDGiRgSBiUJdeTDD.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kDGiRgSBiUJdeTDD.full -->

## 38. Step 38
- The final component to install on the circuit board is the central processing unit, or CPU—the brains of the Brain Game.
- One end of the CPU has a small notch in it. When installing the CPU, make sure that this notch lines up with the cutout on the IC socket.
- Install the CPU by pressing the eight pins into their respective holes in the IC socket.
- Congratulations, you have completed the Level 1 Through-Hole Soldering Kit!
![Step 38 Image 121270](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TCWJ3ULPyypeqMOs.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TCWJ3ULPyypeqMOs.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TCWJ3ULPyypeqMOs.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TCWJ3ULPyypeqMOs.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/TCWJ3ULPyypeqMOs.full -->
![Step 38 Image 121271](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JlvBKD3SHs4gXfBm.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JlvBKD3SHs4gXfBm.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JlvBKD3SHs4gXfBm.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JlvBKD3SHs4gXfBm.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/JlvBKD3SHs4gXfBm.full -->
![Step 38 Image 121272](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VHhQsL1dGHrLk3sr.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VHhQsL1dGHrLk3sr.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VHhQsL1dGHrLk3sr.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VHhQsL1dGHrLk3sr.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VHhQsL1dGHrLk3sr.full -->

## 39. Step 39
- Install three AA batteries in the battery compartment.
- Upon inserting the final battery, the four LEDs should start flashing in a clockwise pattern. Congratulations, you did it!
- To play the game, follow these instructions:
  - Remove one of the batteries. Then, reinsert the battery while holding the Level 2 button for no sound or the Level 1 button for sound. Release the button a couple seconds after the battery is inserted. The game will eventually power off on its own. To wake it up to play, press either the Level 1 button to play with sound, or the Level 2 button to play without sound.
  - As the LEDs blink in a clockwise rotation, press one of the four buttons to select the level of difficulty (printed above or below the buttons).
  - After selecting your level, the game begins. It is a typical Simon Says-like memory game. The LEDs will flash one light, then you have to click that button. Then it will flash two lights and you have to click those two buttons in order.
  - The game progresses until you mess up the pattern or take too long to respond.
- Have fun! And be sure to tell us all about your high scores in our Story section.
![Step 39 Image 121273](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vxnH6fITWW6rxPQR.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vxnH6fITWW6rxPQR.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vxnH6fITWW6rxPQR.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vxnH6fITWW6rxPQR.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vxnH6fITWW6rxPQR.full -->
![Step 39 Image 121274](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tVTwweumnxvFkUyy.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tVTwweumnxvFkUyy.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tVTwweumnxvFkUyy.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tVTwweumnxvFkUyy.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tVTwweumnxvFkUyy.full -->

guides.title: iFixit 26 Bit Driver Kit Technique for Removing Bits
guides.raw_content:
# iFixit 26 Bit Driver Kit Technique for Removing Bits

Consider this a meta-guide...that is, a guide that enables other guides. Before you remove any screws, you need to use the right bit, but getting those out of the tightly packed storage area and into your driver can be a chore in itself.

## 1. Step 1
- Note how challenging it is to remove a required bit from the kit. Argh!
![Step 1 Image 142662](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FWPglfdhhmToOZ5G.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FWPglfdhhmToOZ5G.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FWPglfdhhmToOZ5G.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FWPglfdhhmToOZ5G.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FWPglfdhhmToOZ5G.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Find yourself a rubber band...
![Step 2 Image 142664](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kwPlsNLHxj5CVQJO.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kwPlsNLHxj5CVQJO.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kwPlsNLHxj5CVQJO.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kwPlsNLHxj5CVQJO.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/kwPlsNLHxj5CVQJO.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- Wrap said band around the bit and viola! easy bit extraction enabled. You might want to keep that handy rubber band with the kit now.
![Step 3 Image 142665](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6pmJbWBWmTByJIUR.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6pmJbWBWmTByJIUR.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6pmJbWBWmTByJIUR.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6pmJbWBWmTByJIUR.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/6pmJbWBWmTByJIUR.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- Alternate, no-rubber-band solution: use the [product|IF145-020|tweezers] supplied in the bit driver kit.
![Step 4 Image 245674](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VcTdJFkJFANNxK1F.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VcTdJFkJFANNxK1F.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VcTdJFkJFANNxK1F.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VcTdJFkJFANNxK1F.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/VcTdJFkJFANNxK1F.full -->

## Conclusion

To reassemble your device, follow these instructions in reverse order.

flags.title: Community-Contributed Guide

guides.title: Easter Egg Teardown
guides.raw_content:
# Easter Egg Teardown

I delve into an Easter egg just to see what makes this funky pink thing tick.

## 1. Step 1
- So let's find out what's inside this DELICIOUS-looking Easter egg.
![Step 1 Image 158135](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WGDXXXBJUEyj3sdD.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WGDXXXBJUEyj3sdD.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WGDXXXBJUEyj3sdD.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WGDXXXBJUEyj3sdD.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WGDXXXBJUEyj3sdD.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- First step - cut into the egg.
- I wonder what kinds of things I'll find inside? Leprechauns? Little bunnies? The true meaning of [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Easter|Easter]? Only time will tell.
![Step 2 Image 158128](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IUAHwZCcClSiXdqU.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IUAHwZCcClSiXdqU.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IUAHwZCcClSiXdqU.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IUAHwZCcClSiXdqU.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/IUAHwZCcClSiXdqU.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- The innards reveal a yellowy substance. Not sure what it is, but let's dig into it some more and see if we can find out.
![Step 3 Image 158133](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mlSY6MOEALVWgVuq.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mlSY6MOEALVWgVuq.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mlSY6MOEALVWgVuq.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mlSY6MOEALVWgVuq.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mlSY6MOEALVWgVuq.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- Another cut is made, more yellow is found.
- Surprisingly, no [guide|8277|processors] have so far been found. No bunnies for that matter, either.
![Step 4 Image 158136](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PERWthAGsHVdKB1s.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PERWthAGsHVdKB1s.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PERWthAGsHVdKB1s.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PERWthAGsHVdKB1s.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/PERWthAGsHVdKB1s.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- Two halves exposed... But what's the yellow stuff? Only one way to find out.
- Current bill of materials:
  - Yellow mystery stuff inside
  - Pink outer layer
  - Blue swirls
  - Yellow dots
  - Red Swirls
  - Green swirls
![Step 5 Image 158130](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HmDXtuflEsIJOrOT.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HmDXtuflEsIJOrOT.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HmDXtuflEsIJOrOT.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HmDXtuflEsIJOrOT.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HmDXtuflEsIJOrOT.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- A formal analysis found that the yellow inner filling was, in fact, yellow cake.
- Conclusion: Easter eggs rock!
![Step 6 Image 158134](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WUCqUOygSgi1fHtM.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WUCqUOygSgi1fHtM.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WUCqUOygSgi1fHtM.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WUCqUOygSgi1fHtM.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/WUCqUOygSgi1fHtM.full -->
