guides.title: Sew a Straight Stitch
guides.raw_content:
# Sew a Straight Stitch

A straight stitch is the bread and butter of sewing. This basic stitch will sew two pieces of material together, and can be used in many repairs.

The trick is to take small, even stitches. With a little practice, you can master this basic stitch and repair your textiles.

## 1. Step 1
- [guide|21024|Thread your needle] and tie a knot in the end of the thread.
> **Note:** We're using contrasting thread for visibility, but when you do your repair you will want to use matching thread.
- Drive the needle through the back of the bottom material.
- Pull the thread taut.
![Step 1 Image 309935](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4i3t1kJJQXX2bf5L.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4i3t1kJJQXX2bf5L.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4i3t1kJJQXX2bf5L.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4i3t1kJJQXX2bf5L.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/4i3t1kJJQXX2bf5L.full -->
![Step 1 Image 309934](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HYLChXZvSMgRhGiG.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HYLChXZvSMgRhGiG.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HYLChXZvSMgRhGiG.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HYLChXZvSMgRhGiG.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/HYLChXZvSMgRhGiG.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- Drive the needle through the back side of the top material.
> **Note:** In this case we're sewing a buckle, but you can use this stitch to sew just about anything together.
- Pull the thread taut.
- Align the two materials in their final position.
![Step 2 Image 309933](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FIltD6DAilHNqDKr.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FIltD6DAilHNqDKr.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FIltD6DAilHNqDKr.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FIltD6DAilHNqDKr.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/FIltD6DAilHNqDKr.full -->
![Step 2 Image 309936](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EjyjjAyuEuvWUHff.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EjyjjAyuEuvWUHff.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EjyjjAyuEuvWUHff.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EjyjjAyuEuvWUHff.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/EjyjjAyuEuvWUHff.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- Drive the needle down through both layers of material, coming out on the back side of the bottom material. Push the needle out of the material.
> **Note:** The closer you drive the needle in to where the thread came up, the smaller the stitch length. Having a smaller stitch length requires more stitches, but creates a stronger seam.
- Pull the thread taut.
![Step 3 Image 309931](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5x2Klrl2BG1SDELA.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5x2Klrl2BG1SDELA.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5x2Klrl2BG1SDELA.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5x2Klrl2BG1SDELA.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5x2Klrl2BG1SDELA.full -->
![Step 3 Image 309929](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tZQEbnFoXShQdmEE.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tZQEbnFoXShQdmEE.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tZQEbnFoXShQdmEE.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tZQEbnFoXShQdmEE.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tZQEbnFoXShQdmEE.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- Ensure the two layers are correctly aligned.
- Drive the needle through both layers of fabric from the back side of the bottom material, coming up on the top side of the top material.
- Pull the thread taut.
![Step 4 Image 309927](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1WjMrYPKuJDQAMtP.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1WjMrYPKuJDQAMtP.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1WjMrYPKuJDQAMtP.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1WjMrYPKuJDQAMtP.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/1WjMrYPKuJDQAMtP.full -->
![Step 4 Image 309938](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AJrsHLFZ1HRIiMe.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AJrsHLFZ1HRIiMe.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AJrsHLFZ1HRIiMe.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AJrsHLFZ1HRIiMe.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5AJrsHLFZ1HRIiMe.full -->

## 5. Step 5
- Continue sewing through both layers, going down from the top and up from the bottom, as described in steps 3 and 4 of this guide.
- When you come to the end of your material, draw the needle in between the two layers of material, under the thread of the closest stitch.
- Slowly start to pull the thread taut. As you pull a loop will form.
- Draw the needle through the loop and pull the thread taut.
- Repeat the process of drawing the needle between the layers, creating a loop, and drawing the needle through the loop as described in this step.
![Step 5 Image 309928](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MyAkguGDEZjIbXNs.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MyAkguGDEZjIbXNs.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MyAkguGDEZjIbXNs.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MyAkguGDEZjIbXNs.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/MyAkguGDEZjIbXNs.full -->
![Step 5 Image 309939](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3GWPrKX3Pj2YOLgH.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3GWPrKX3Pj2YOLgH.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3GWPrKX3Pj2YOLgH.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3GWPrKX3Pj2YOLgH.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/3GWPrKX3Pj2YOLgH.full -->
![Step 5 Image 309923](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5FhFTRW25CFXCqXL.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5FhFTRW25CFXCqXL.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5FhFTRW25CFXCqXL.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5FhFTRW25CFXCqXL.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/5FhFTRW25CFXCqXL.full -->

## 6. Step 6
- Pull the thread taut.
- Cut any remaining thread and admire your work.
![Step 6 Image 309941](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/XVMpBj2Y2t36MsS1.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/XVMpBj2Y2t36MsS1.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/XVMpBj2Y2t36MsS1.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/XVMpBj2Y2t36MsS1.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/XVMpBj2Y2t36MsS1.full -->

guides.title: Adding images to an existing question
guides.raw_content:
# Adding images to an existing question

This is a "quick and dirty" guide on how to add images to existing questions or answers.

## 1. Step 1
- Mouse-over '''Options''' on the top right corner of the Question field to reveal a dropdown menu.
- Click on '''Edit''' to open the Edit Post page.
- Before adding your image, position the cursor at the place in your text where you want to add the image. We suggest placing it at the end of the question.
- Click on the image icon to open the Media Manager.
- Click on '''Add Media''' and select files from your computer to upload.
> **Note:** Alternatively, you can simply drag and drop images into the Media Manager to upload them. '''If you did this, proceed directly to step 3.'''
![Step 1 Image 842566](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vRiFCKxvJGCJGDIH.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vRiFCKxvJGCJGDIH.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vRiFCKxvJGCJGDIH.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vRiFCKxvJGCJGDIH.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/vRiFCKxvJGCJGDIH.full -->
![Step 1 Image 842567](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tLnryYUhuMQTGTov.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tLnryYUhuMQTGTov.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tLnryYUhuMQTGTov.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tLnryYUhuMQTGTov.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/tLnryYUhuMQTGTov.full -->
![Step 1 Image 842568](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RBrFCavfCIkfl5NV.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RBrFCavfCIkfl5NV.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RBrFCavfCIkfl5NV.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RBrFCavfCIkfl5NV.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/RBrFCavfCIkfl5NV.full -->

## 2. Step 2
- In the Add Media window, you can add images from the internet or your local machine.
- To add images from your computer:
  - Click on the '''browse for files''' to find photos on your computer, or simply drag and drop them onto the window.
- To add images from the internet:
  - Get the link to your desired image. You can usually do this by right-clicking the image and selecting '''Copy link address'''.
  - Paste the link into the field provided.
  - Click '''Grab Media''' to add the image to your Media Manager.
![Step 2 Image 842576](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mOsDKuYecJnNhbZL.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mOsDKuYecJnNhbZL.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mOsDKuYecJnNhbZL.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mOsDKuYecJnNhbZL.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/mOsDKuYecJnNhbZL.full -->

## 3. Step 3
- Once the image is in your Media Manager, click on it to insert into your question.
- The image should appear in-line at the spot where your cursor was positioned when you opened the Media Manager.
> **Note:** iFixit images show up in 4:3 format. Most modern cameras capture in 3:2 or 16:9, which will require a crop. If you change your capturing preferences when taking pictures to 4:3,  you won't need to crop them in the Media Manager.
![Step 3 Image 842582](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lV11S4Ek3MoStkXn.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lV11S4Ek3MoStkXn.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lV11S4Ek3MoStkXn.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lV11S4Ek3MoStkXn.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/lV11S4Ek3MoStkXn.full -->
![Step 3 Image 842584](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZWFrCvSNS6u1SZmo.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZWFrCvSNS6u1SZmo.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZWFrCvSNS6u1SZmo.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZWFrCvSNS6u1SZmo.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/ZWFrCvSNS6u1SZmo.full -->

## 4. Step 4
- After inserting the image, scroll to the bottom of the page and click '''Preview Edit'''.
  - A preview will be automatically inserted below the fields for you to review.
- If everything looks good, click '''Submit Edit'''. If not, scroll back up and adjust your question as necessary.
![Step 4 Image 842590](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dMgAEA1mwGyNpRKF.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dMgAEA1mwGyNpRKF.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dMgAEA1mwGyNpRKF.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dMgAEA1mwGyNpRKF.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/dMgAEA1mwGyNpRKF.full -->
![Step 4 Image 842591](https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rbQIfZBvoeGcbdZZ.full)
<!-- Image URLs: thumbnail=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rbQIfZBvoeGcbdZZ.thumbnail, medium=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rbQIfZBvoeGcbdZZ.medium, large=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rbQIfZBvoeGcbdZZ.large, original=https://guide-images.cdn.ifixit.com/igi/rbQIfZBvoeGcbdZZ.full -->

## Conclusion

The image size for insertion must be 800 x 600 pixels otherwise there will be an error message in the Media Manager. It looks complicated, but is actually straightforward.
